title: go vape e cigs better than regular cigarettes
story: But it isn’t.They also think that because you are inhaling nicotine in the vapour of e-cigarettes you are just as likely to get lung cancer as you would smoking tobacco.You are not.There are also worries that vaping will act as a gateway for young people, who have never smoked, to progress to traditional cigarettes and ruin their health as a result.They are fears, too, that it will “normalise” smoking again just when public health campaigns are managing to help more people permanently quit smoking than ever before.All the evidence, however, says that this just is not the case.Don’t get me wrong, as a doctor I’d prefer itnobody smoked OR vaped.Years ago, as medical students, who should have known better, many of us smoked a little — often to disguise the awful, lingering smell of the cadavers we had to dissect in the anatomy room.But we soon stopped when we saw with our own eyes what the long-term effects of smoking did to the human body.In the Pathology Museum we would see a nice healthy pink lung sat pickled in a jar of formaldehyde right next to another lung, black with tar and soot from smoking, at the centre of which was a hard, pearly white grapefruit-sized knuckle of cancer with tentacles reaching out into other adjacent organs including the liver and brain.Smoking kills.Later, as qualied doctors on the wards, we saw the horrendous consequences of it.People who could not breathe without oxygen tanks, people suffering heart attacks or strokes, or undergoing amputations or voicebox removal for throat cancer.We saw — and still see — the damage done to unborn babies of expectant mothers, who remain addicted, and the increased risk of chest and ear infections from passive smoking, and meningitis and leukaemia in infants, who live in smoking households.The medical evidence is irrefutable. Smoking tobacco is bad news.But vaping is dferent.You heat up a solution called an e-liquid, which typically contains nicotine, a propellant called propylene glycol and or vegetable glycerin and flavourings.What you don’t do is burn tobacco or produce tar or carbon monoxide — two of the most harmful elements of all in tobacco smoke.Sure, some vapes may contain a fraction of some of the harmful chemicals found in cigarette smoke, but they are present at much lower levels,detectable at all.So are they safe  According to all the international medically-reviewed evidence from such expert organisations as Public Health England, the Royal Colleges of Physicians and General Practitioners, the British Medical Association and Cancer Research UK, e-cigarettes are at least  per cent safer than traditional cigarettes.The American Cancer Society and the National Academies of Science, Engineering and Medicine both agree with them.Yes, the nicotine, of course, is addictive. But so what  So is caffeine, even eating.Contrary to popular belief, nicotine does not give you cancer and it is relatively harmless generally.Apparently only  per cent of the population know this.Happily, there is no evidence of harm to other people from vaping and,used instead of nicotine replacement gum or patches, may even help expectant mums remain smoke-free in the long term.As a doctor I don’t want any young person or non-nicotine user to try vaping. Ever. Period.As it happens, regular use of e-cigs among “never” smokers is still very rare at just . per cent.But look at what they’ve done to help tobacco smokers quit.In the UK, .million vapers have quit smoking completely and more than , have given up both smoking and vaping.In fact, this is Britain’s most popular method of quitting with two-thirds stopping successfully when used alongside professional stop-smoking NHS support.In this country we have some of the strictest regulations in the world.E-cigs are subject to minimum standards of quality and safety as well as clear packaging and labelling requirements.All ingredients have to be notied, advertising is prohibited in media such as television, newspapers and magazines, it is illegal to sell them to under s and to adults intending to pass them on to under s.That is responsible regulation whichever way you look at it.This month’s national Stoptober campaign recommends using e- cigarettes as a stop-smoking aid andit helps some of the million smokers in the UK kick the habit for good then perhaps doctors like me will see fewer people in our surgeries struggling to breath or devastated by a cancer diagnosis.AndI see any ex-smoking patients of mine having a quiet vape outside my surgery door, I shall give them a heartfelt pat on the back and cherish the fact that there will be one less nasty fag end polluting the street.NICOTINE contained in e-liquids is a highly addictive substance that raises blood pressure and spikes your adrenalin, increasing the chances of having a heart attack.This is particularly worrying as we see a number of iniduals who are constantly vaping, especially as it is seen as more convenient and cost-effective than lighting up a cigarette, as well as being considered more socially acceptable to vape indoors.While vaping appears to be safer than cigarettes, the truth is that it hasn’t been around long enough for us to know the potential damage it can cause to our health.The long-term effects of the chemicals contained in e-liquids haven’t been examined.However, I have looked into ious research that has been carried out on certain e-liquids that were found to contain substances that can cause damage to the immune system and are linked to other health conditions such as cancer.Vaping isn’t great for your oral health either.It’s common for vaping to cause a dry mouth, and I’ve met a number of iniduals who have developed oral thrush, most likely caused by vaping.Although nicotine does not have a colour, it becomes yellow when combined with oxygen which could lead to tooth discolouration.As nicotine is a vasocon-strictor, it limits blood flow in oral tissue, which can cause gum disease and bad breath.As time goes on, I am reading new research which proves vaping has a negative effect on health.To what extent, only time will tell.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: this morning universal credit single mum debt school uniforms
story: Stacey Gleave told ITVs This Morning that Brits on benefits were left with no safety net when they went on to the new system - as they have to wait five weeks to get a payment.She said she was forced into arrears when she went onto Universal Credit and still owes hundreds which she now cant pay off.People are having literally to live out of food banks, she told the programme. The problem for us is that we have been left with no safety net.In between we are left with nothing, youve got no back up behind you.Those who transfer onto Universal Credit are offered advance loans, which have steep repayment rates that come out of their next payment.Stacey says shes £ in debt since transferring over, and has been left in arrears.And since her kid moved school, she hasnt even been able to afford his new unorm.He was coming home and asking me why he was dferent... the real reason was I couldnt afford the unorm, she admitted.Luckily Stacey has been able to borrow money from her family to keep her going, but now owes them hundreds of pounds.It just adds all on to your debt, she says. Debt puts a big hold on you, it plays a big part in your le.Every day you wake up with the worries... What can you do to get out of it  There is nothing.Shes also been forced to controversial rent-to-own firm BrightHouse, which provides goods with sky-high interest rates.Customers are lured in by what the firm calls “affordable weekly repayments” - which might be something like £ a week for a flash Samsung TV.But the plans can go on for years, by which time you may have ended up paying more than double for your goods, as high lighted in our Stop the Credit Rip-Off campaignApply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently, or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.The Sun revealed last week how families on Universal Credit are being forced to turn to payday loans to make ends meet.The Governments new flagship benefits system has been beset with problems since it started being rolled out across the country.It takes five weeks for the first payment to come through on Universal Credit, but some have been left waiting for months after that.Ministers are being urged to plug the gap in funding Universal Credit in next weeks Budget, so the millions that are yet to be transferred over wont lose out.The DWP says the vast majority of people on Universal Credit are satisfied, and their test and learn approach means that any problems are continuously being ironed out.

story: MPs are pressuring the Chancellor to reverse cuts to the welfare budget in next week’s fiscal statement, which could make le easier for up to , Brits.The cuts were made under ex-Chancellor George Osborne, and would mean that some Brits won’t be better off under the new Universal Credit system.The rollout, which has been plagued with problems so far, is set to be take place across the whole country next year.New analysis from the Resolution Foundation shows thatthe cuts to work allowances were reversed back to the sort of system that was in place before, around , fewer people would lose out.Most would be at least £ a week better offministers ed to the old system - You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Millions more are set to go onto Universal Credit in the coming months - as it continues its rollout across the country.But last week it was revealed that its set to be paused in order to try and fix some of the problems in the system - and more money could be pumped in to make sure that Brits don’t lose out.Many claimants say they don’t get their payments under the new system for many weeks after they are told they will - and end up being pushed into debt as a result.Some are forced into arrears on their rent and bills - and others have even had to resort to prostitution as a result, one MP said.

title: karren brady on women at work
story: I wanted to stop her right there and ask: “What on earth are you sorry about  Why don’t you know your worth “Why don’t you have ­confidence in the contribution you make ”It left me wondering why so many talented and competent women lack confidence at work to get the best out of their job. Why do they not get paid what they are worth to their company, and why are so many overlooked for promotion The sad fact is that for every £ men earn, women make just  pence.Just over one in ten women negotiated their starting salary, while more than half of all men haggle with their boss before they have even started work.When women do ask for more pay, they are  per cent less likely to get a raise. Andthey do receive a wage increase it will be  per cent less than men get.Sadly, it is common in business that women are often viewed as weak or unable to cope. And once we think about or start a family, we become toxic to employers.I receive hundreds of direct messages on social media from women asking: “How do I get a pay rise  How do I get noticed at work  How can I get promoted  How can I get on after maternity leave ”So now I am launching Get What You Want, a series of online masterclasses and podcasts covering everything from getting promoted to dealing with the word no, overcoming challenges, negotiating pay, writing a fantastic CV and nailing an interview.It will also cover baby-proofing careers, as well as becoming a super-mum after maternity leave.A lot of women have skills but just lack confidence. As women, we don’t shout about our wins enough for fear we will appear arrogant, even though men talk about them all the time.Here are some of my tips to winning at work.When people say: “I hate my job” I always ask: “Why are you telling me  I can’t do anything about it.”YOU have to do something. Sit down and work out what it is you don’t like about the position and set yourself a task of getting a new one.Be very dedicated and very professional and excel when you get to the interview.Many people don’t realise that when you are invited for an interview it is because they believe you can do the job.The secret is convincing them that you can do the job better than anyone .You should be able to talk about your specialist subject, which is yourself.People find it very dficult to list all the things they have done really well in a professional way to show good examples of why they can do the job.Opening a negotiation is all about knowing your worth.And knowing your value is really about your self-worth. They are totally linked.Write down all the things where you have made a big ­contribution, all the things that you have changed and made a dference, how you have added value. Put together testimonials to really back up what you have done.Then work out what more you want to do, because going above and beyond your job description is very important.Take out all the emotion, go in and lay out for your boss the facts of what you’ve contributed to the organisation.Sometimes people can be very passive. They say: “I’ll go along with what everyone  agrees with.”They want to avoid conflict. They don’t really think their opinion is as important as other people’s, so they are simply giving others a licence to ignore them.Learn to say no. Say: “I don’t really have the time butI can make the time I can do it for you.” Otherwise you become like a human sponge. Don’t let them take advantage.Employers take advantage of women’s lack of confidence, especially a mother ing from maternity leave. Many feel so grateful to have a job that they tend to put up with almost anything.Eleven per cent of new mothers report that they have been dismissed or made redundant where others in their workplace were not, or were treated so poorly they felt they had to leave.That means as many as , women are losing their jobs each year.Have a really clear plan of how you will manage at home and manage work. Get your partner to do his share  — and by that I mean half.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says may transition period
story: It is a trap, designed to keep us locked in to the EU racket.There’s nothing unreasonable about what Mrs May demanded yesterday — a backstop with a definite end date.Tusk, Barnier and Juncker will no doubt tell us it’s impossible.They will say “non” to any proposal we come up with, until the final seconds tick on the Brexit clock.The PM must hold her nerve. Because when it suits them, it’s amazing how many times the EU has shown a sudden flexibility.They are more than happy to break their sacred rules when it’s politically useful.They should be fining Italy for their illegal budget — but won’t, because it would stir a hornet’s nest of anti-EU feeling in a founder member.Brussels’ leaders do at least seem to understand we’re coming to the crunch.Unlike Leo Varadkar, the talkative Irish PM who is yet to see a microphone he didn’t like or miss an opportunity to undermine the UK.While our PM is giving statements in the Commons, this wannabe statesman is busy making jokes on Twitter about bailing Britain outBrexit goes badly.Ditch the jokes, Leo. The PM knows that, and has done everything possible to get a deal.Now it’s Brussels’ turn.HAS the sun finally come out in Hundred Acre Wood Eeyore Chancellor Philip Hammond is reportedly considering a tax cut for struggling High Street businesses in next week’s Budget.About time too. Shops and pubs have been on the sharp end of business rate hikes, with many left at death’s door.A tax break would be a welcome sticking plaster, but in truth the rates system needs root and branch reform.The Chancellor must start on the second half of the High Street puzzle, too.Taxing the tech giants should be a Budget priority.MPs cannot be allowed to mark their own homework on bullying in Parliament.The evidence of a toxic culture in the House of Commons is compelling. title: big cat panther spotted park hertfordshire
story: Tom Pitt, , says he saw the beast in the grounds of Hatfield House on Sunday.It comes after cops in Scotland were put on panther alert when a big cat was spotted in Ayrshire.He claimed it was bigger than a domestic cat - and managed to snap a photograph.Tom told EssexLive: I think it was my dog who noticed first. He kind of looked in that direction and so I looked, and it was a big black cat.It looked like a domestic cat but much bigger.We made eye contact with it and began to walk towards it. It looked like it growled and bared its teeth.It ran into the woods after that. I think we startled it, it was all so quick.I have been walking over there for years and Ive never seen anything like it before. You dont expect to see that kind of thing.It was the morning and I was barely awake. You see the deer and hedgehogs but not a big cat.RSPCA confirmed no sightings matching the beasts description have been reported in the park.

title: 1917 russian revolution lenin stalin colourised images
story: Striking pictures show Vladimir Lenin disguised as factory worker KP Ivanov at Razliz station in August  as well as Lenin with Joseph Stalin in .Other stunning colour shots show the last Tsar of Russia, Nicholas II with his family and visiting the army in , the Tsar family executor Jakob Jurovsky and the February revolution taking place in .The original black and white photographs were painstakingly colourised by artist Viacheslav Peregudov, , from Irkutsk, Russia.He said: “The crowds were intoxicated by freedom soldiers mixed with civilians.”“The first was the February revolution, which screamed in the squares about equality and brotherhood, followed by the Bolshevik revolution, the civil war.“And youre looking for the point where the giant Empire began its descent to the edge of the abyss.”He continued: “One of the greatest dreams of any person in the world is a time machine. And the greatest regret of any person is that it is impossible to produce this machine in our world.“Not in our time at least but who knows maybe in  years. For now we can do it just in our imagination.“I would say my time machine works on a fuel of imagination and the real colour of the past which is a channel of reality that has been ignored for many years due to black and white images.”The Russian Revolution was a pair of revolutions in Russia in  which dismantled the Tsarist autocracy and led to the rise of the Soviet Union.The Russian Empire collapsed with the abdication of Emperor Nicholas II and the old regime was replaced by a provisional government during the first revolution of February .In the October Revolution, the Bolsheviks led an armed insurrection by workers and soldiers in Petrograd that successfully overthrew the Provisional Government, transferring all its authority to the soviets with the capital being relocated to Moscow shortly thereafter.Soon after, civil war erupted among the Reds , the Whites , the independence movements and the non-Bolshevik socialists.It continued for several years, during which the Bolsheviks defeated both the Whites and all rival socialists and thereafter reconstituted themselves as the Communist Party.In this way, the Revolution paved the way for the creation of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republicsin .Viacheslav began to colourise old photographs around five years ago and was quickly drawn to images of Russia in the early th Century.He added: “When I started my project, it was just a few historical photos.“I didn’t do it for money but just my private pleasure and today it is a collection of more than  colourised photos that were shot in the period from  to .“Sometimes I do colourisation for other photographs but I alwaysto Russia in the early s.”

title: theresa may faces down cabinet critics tory backbench not enough support
story: The PM wants to avoid striking a Brexit deal which would carve off Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK.Her alternative proposal will see the whole of the UK stay in the EUs customs unionthat is the only way to avoid a hard border in Ireland.Brussels chiefs have previously resisted that suggestion - claiming it would be too dficult to sort out the details in time for Brexit.But today RTE reported that the EU has accepted Mrs Mays plans could be workable as long as both sides sign a separate treaty to enshrine it into law.The compromise brings Britain and the EU a step closer to signing a deal which would ensure a smooth Brexit next year.In another victory for the PM, it emerged today that Tory rebels still arent strong enough to kick her out of office.Backbenchers have mounted a bid to topple Mrs by putting in letters calling for a vote of confidence in her leadership.But the Tory shop steward shot down rumours that the revolt has attracted enough support to unseat Mrs May - meaning she is still safe for now.Graham Brady, chair of the  Committee of backbenchers, must call a vote of confidencehe gets  letters demanding one.After Westminster insiders claimed the threshold had already been reached, Sir Graham told friends the rumours were wrong.He is the only person who knows how many letters have been submitted at any given time.During this mornings Cabinet meeting, Mrs May told ministers she is planning to produce weekly reports on the Brexit talks from now on.The PM will also brief them regularly on how the Government is preparing for a possible No Deal scenario.The briefings are meant to be a show of strength - proving to Brussels that the UK is ready for all possible outcomes.Mrs Mays spokesman said: As we move towards exit day it makes good sense that all ministers are informed about the work taking place for both scenarios.The PM told the Cabinet her priority is preparing for a withdrawal agreement, but stressed Britain will be prepared evenwe leave the EU without a deal.She said Brussels bosses will call an emergency Brexit summit as soon as enough progress has been made to secure a deal.Amber Rudd today dismissed the idea that Mrs May could be unseated by furious Brexiteers.She told the BBC: I do think that shes safe - controversial I know.The fact is, whoever was leading the Conservative party now would have the same problem with the numbers. The numbers are that the MPs are ided on how to leave the European Union.

title: glasgow explosion bang city centre
story: Paramedics treated two people for minor injuries at a scrapyard in the Whiteinch area of the city after residents reported hearing loud bangs.A Scottish Fire and Rescue Service spokeswoman told The Sun Online: We were alerted at .pm to reports of a contained explosion involving a gas cylinder.Operations control were mobilised  and four fire engines attended the scene in South Street.Firefighters are currently working alongside partners to make the area safe.”A Police Scotland spokeswoman confirmed that officers had attended the EMR Scrapyard. One resident, who did not want to be named, told Glasgow Live they heard a loud bang and could hear alarms going off.They said: It was a massive big boom, it was scary and our house shook.Another speculated it sounded like a gas explosion.They added: Windows were shaking and you could hear house and car alarms going off.Witnesses have had said they heard a loud bang and one has reported seeing a ball of smoke.

title: keira knightley disney ban jane moore opinion
story: Sigh. Ms Knightley, who adds, “Rescue yourself,” clearly feels she is protecting daughter Edie by banning something that doesn’t concur with her own off-the-shelf, Poundland version of what feminism should be.But what she’s in danger of doing is wilfully nurturing a potential “snowflake” who, rather than develop the critical thinking skills that allow healthy debate, will simply stick their fingers in their ears and cry foul when they see or hear something that dfers from their own world view.Keira, tonight’s homework is to really readCinderella and analyse it.Look past the Disney-esque cute rodents, pretty frocks and glass slippers and instead dig a little deeper to ­appreciate the original’s narrative of how hope can turn unjust oppression into ­triumphant reward.Cinderella is a young woman who has not only suffered the loss of her loving father, but now faces a letime of abuse from an uncaring stepmother and her equally unpleasant daughters.But instead of sitting in the ashes ­waiting unquestioningly for whatever fate might have in store for her, she remains resolutely ­optimistic and decides to secretly defy her nemesis by gatecrashing a hot-ticket party to which she hasn’t been invited.Now that’s girl power.Ultimately, she “‘rescues” herself by proactively going to the ball where, instead of abuse, she experiences the redemptive qualities of love and kindness.They just happen to come in the form of a handsome prince.In the same week, Kristen Bell — who coincidentally voices Anna in the Disney film Frozen — found herself caught up in the slipstream of Keira’s PC virtue signalling after reportedly saying that Snow White gives young girls the wrong ­message about consent “because you cannot kiss someonethey’re sleeping”.Except Kristen’s comment was taken out of context and she’s got the balance right.Because what she actually said was that she reads the story with her two ­daughters, aged five and three, then asks them: “Don’t you think it’s weird that Snow White didn’t ask the old witch why she needed to eat the apple ” before starting up a conversation about the dos and don’ts of taking food from strangers.Or, “Don’t you think that it’s weird that the prince kisses Snow White without her permission ” to float an almost subliminal, age-appropriate understanding of what does and doesn’t constitute ­consent.Kristen isn’t banning tales of old, she’s using them to stimulate discussions.In other words, teaching her children the vital le skills of critical thinking — dictionary definition: “the objective analysis and evaluation of an issue in order to form a judgment” — and being able to rationally debate that judgment with someone whose view might dfer from your own.Attempting to sanitise a child’s world by airbrushing history will hinder, not help them.Instead, wield history’s lessons as a tool to educate.Cinderella was of its time and now the Disney pendulum has seemingly swung the other way to depict a world where all the central characters are feisty, opinionated young women who power-kick their way through le.But how will Keira’s daughter know how far the depiction of Disney ­princesses has comeshe’s not allowed to see where they’ve been ONE morning last week, I spent a glorious couple of hours walking around Westminster Abbey.Buried or commemorated there are, among others, more than , great Britonsincluding Sir Isaac Newton, Jane Austen, Noel Coward, Charles Darwin, the Bronte sisters, Clement Attlee, Charles Dickens, David Livingstone, Stephen Hawking and, of course, the grave of the unknown warrior, buried on November ,  “in honour of the many multitudes who during the Great War of - gave the most that man can give . . . le itself.”My mother works at the Abbey as a “blue-gowner” – the volunteer guides there to answer any questions not covered by the electronic headsets – and, while showing us the ft by ft grave of poet Ben Jonson, who is the only person there to be buried upright, she was approached by a couple of earnest-looking women in their early twenties.Amid such a rich seam of history, rigorous intellect and achievement, what did they ask “Excuse me, where did David Beckham sit for the royal wedding ”THE number of stay-at-home dads has dropped to the lowest level in five years.Experts reckon it could be due to men “growing tired” of the tough job of raising kids.Proof,needed, might be the glassy-eyed expression of Bond actor Daniel Craig,  just six weeks after we Rachel Weisz gave birth to their daughter.He never looks this knackered when he’s jumping off buildings and dodging bullets.Stay-at-home parenthood can be isolating, sometimes dull, frequently thankless and relentlessly bloody exhausting. Only the strong survive it.THANKS to Ryanair’s ­astonishing failure to act when a passenger racially abused Windrush immigrant Delsie Gayle on one of its flights, the man will likely escape prosecution because of jurisdictional issues once a plane takes off from one country’s airspace to another.Instead, he is likely only to be banned from ever travelling on Ryanair again.Which, as plenty of the budget airline’s past ­customers might tell you, could equally be regarded as a blessing rather than a punishment.COMEDIAN Seann Walsh and his Strictly partner Katya Jones have survived the dreaded dance-off to, presumably, jive another day.Because, let’s face it, since that snog, the Strictly bosses are ­rapidly running out of drearily chaste dances to give them.Last weekend it was the unsexy Charleston, ­performed in equally unsexy “Where’s Wally” outfits that virtually screamed “nothing to see here”. Then this weekend it was a faintly ­ludicrous, undeniably platonic quickstep that saw them trotting around the floor like a couple of hyperactive show ponies.Assuming the sizzling Argentine tango is, er, strictly no-go, whatever next  A jive in burkas  A Viennese waltz in sackcloths Not least from Tom himself, perhaps, whose first we Mimi Rogers bemoaned the lack of intimacy in their union because, she claims, he wanted to be a monk and “thought he had to be celibate to maintain the purity of his instrument, but my instrument needed tuning, and we had to split.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: space views galaxies greenwich observatory photo contest
story: The winning photo, taken in Utah, USA, of an immense rocky landscape set beneath the glorious Milky Way, scooped the top prize of £,.Judges were captivated with winner Brad Goldpaints breathtaking snap that beat thousands of amateur and professional photographers from around the world.Winning images of the other categories include the breathaking Aurora Borealis above a fjord in Norway, Augusts total solar eclipse, and the solar system captured from a Brits back garden.The youngsters category winner was -year-old Italian Fabian Dalpiaz who snapped an incredible photo of a meteor passing over the Alpe di Siusi alpine meadow.The Milky Way contrasted with the Andromeda galaxy in Brad Goldpaints photo had the judges gushing over his entry.Competition judge Will Gater said: For me this superb image is emblematic of everything it means to be an astrophotographer.The balance between light and dark, the contrasting textures and tones of land and sky and the photographer alone under a starry canopy of breathtaking scale and beauty.The competition, named Insight Investment Astronomy Photographer of the Year, is run by the Royal Observatory Greenwich.Now in its tenth year, the contest received over , entries from more than  countries across the globe.A special exhibition at the National Maritime Museum is now open, showcasing ten years of outstanding astrophotography.This years winners will be published in the competitions official book by Collins, available exclusively at Royal Museums Greenwich shops and online from  October, with all major bookstores stocking from  November.

title: rome subway football fans crushed escalator
story: Footage shows crowds of people hurtling into each other after the mal at the Repubblica underground station.The Russian embassy in Italy said that up to  people were injured in the incident ahead of CSKA Moscows Champions League match with Roma.Witnesses quoted by police said Russian fans were singing and jumping on the escalator shortly before it collapsed.Terrying screams can be heard in a video of the collapse as scores of people were sent hurtling towards the bottom.Some passengers were pulled to safety while others scrambled over the central reservation but many were crushed in the mechanism.Part of one victims foot was cut off in the incident, according to La Repubblica.One person told the paper: I just witnessed a scene from the apocalypse.Six people are seriously injured and more than  firefighters have been scrambled to the station.Dmitry Gurin, of the Russian embassy, claimed that  travelling fans were injured, with  taken to hospital.A group of CSKA fans were going down into the station. At that moment the escalator collapsed, a police spokesman told Russian news agency RIA.One photo shared on social media appears to show blood and broken metal at the bottom of the maling escalator.Meanwhile, a Russian fan was stabbed during clashes between fans near the Stadio Olimpico.Two other travelling Moscow fans were also said to have been hurt in the melee.Police were deployed with water cannons to break up the violence between rival fans.

title: ocd app reduce symptoms advice
story: They call it up when they feel the need to scrub their mitts after touching a surface they feel is dirty or contaminated — a classic OCD trigger.In tests, users said watching the video of themselves cleaning their hands eased the compulsion.After a week of viewing the -second videos four times a day, participants reported signicant reductions in their symptoms.The Cambridge University team that developed the app said it has led to a reduction of OCD behaviour by  per cent in some cases.Neuroscientist Baland Jalal said: “Participants told us that the smartphone washing app allowed them to easily engage in their daily activities.“One participant said, ‘If I’m commuting on the bus and touch something contaminated and can’t wash my hands for the next two hours.The app would be a sufficient substitute’.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sarah wellgreen disappearance puzzling cops
story: There seems no reason she should want to disappear.But it is now two weeks since beauty therapist Sarah, , vanished without trace.And with fears for her safety increasing, it is believed her complicated private le may hold vital clues.Police and more than  volunteers have been scouring woods near the home she shares with her ex-partner, Nerf gun fanatic Ben Lacomba, , and their three children — six-year-old twins and a -year-old son.Her car remains at the four-bedroom house in the village of New Ash Green — one of architect Eric Lyons’ radical Sixties Span social housing developments — in the Kent countryside near Dartford.The couple originally split up following the birth of the twins.And Sarah, who has not contacted her family or used her phone or bank card since Tuesday, October , ed to her hometown of Portsmouth.But six months ago, she moved back in with cab driver Ben, with friends saying the couple wanted to bring up the children together.Sarah, who also has two older sons — Lewis Burdett, , and Jack,  — still worked in Portsmouth and is said to have spent time in Surrey, where colleagues believe she had found a new man through online dating.Martin Prus, , her manager at Puresun Hair and Beauty Centre in Portsmouth, told The Sun this week: “She is always in dferent locations. She is a very busy woman.“I know she had been travelling between Portsmouth, Kent and somewhere near Guildford in Surrey.“We know she was connected to at least three areas.“In Portsmouth she was with her eldest sons, and when in Kent she was with her ex-partner.“They were sharing the children, that’s what I know.“When near Guildford she was seeing a man. She had been going there for a few months. I know she had a new boyfriend and I met him once, he was a good guy.”Mr Prus added that Sarah, thought to have been married three times, worked at the salon full-time for around two years before going part-time when she moved back to Kent.She is also believed to own a home in Portsmouth which she rents out.Mr Prus, who last saw her at work on the Saturday before she went missing, said: “Sarah is a strong person, the sort who absolutely loves what she did, which is what makes things even harder.“She is a mother of five and worked hard to look after her kids.“A third party might be the cause of her going missing — otherwise it just doesn’t add up.”On Tuesday last week, police arrested a man in his s for questioning. He has since been released pending further inquiries.Last night, Sarah’s distraught dad Anthony Wellgreen, , said: “I don’t understand it at all. It’s not in her character to disappear like this.“Nothing like this has ever happened before. We are all so worried. Two weeks is a long time to be away.”Her uncle Ronald Wellgreen, , added: “Wherever she went, her kids would go too as they meant absolutely everything to her.“I know she has been back up in Kent recently and at the time she went missing.”According to one neighbour, Sarah moved back in with Ben after she split up with a boyfriend.She said: “For him to have her back is kind. He did the best for them.” Another neighbour, Joe Thomas, described Ben as an “extremely family-oriented man”.He added: “He adores his children and is a great bloke. He’s the local taxi driver and gives lts to people to help them out.“He’s really into his Nerf gun wars, and he would play shooting games with his children.”One of the last sightings of Sarah — who friends describe as a “bubbly” and “friendly” mum — was on the morning she disappeared.Fellow parents at the school gates told The Sun how she appeared fine as they shared a laugh.One dad said: “She made a joke and she was really happy and smiley, not acting strangely or like she was going to disappear.”His partner said: “Sarah was a lovely mum and utterly attentive to her children.”She added that she was “shocked” when Sarah moved back in with her ex in the summer.She said: “Whether her and Ben ended up rekindling things I don’t know, but we never saw them together.”Police have spent several days searching her home as well as trawling through social media and dating sites for clues.She was known to have been hunting for love online over the summer and friends believe this is how she met her new man.Officers have also used drones and dogs to search an area of woods they have cordoned off near her and Ben’s £, terraced home.Over the weekend, police also searched land and fields by a nearby private hospital and pub, and woodland in Ridley, about two miles away from where she lived.Yesterday, search teams moved to Foxborough Woods, Hartley, around a mile from her street.Despite her connections in other counties, Kent Police say no other forces are involved in the investigation.Sarah’s oldest son Lewis has put out several appeals on social media, which have been shared thousands of times.He described his mum’s disappearance as completely out of character, saying that she was “happy, with no problems”.He said that the day before she went missing, she had also found out she had got a new job, adding: “So everything was great”.Kent resident Neil Howick, , who has been using his drone to search woodland, said: “Everybody in the area will continue to work hard to try to find her.”One of the most confused of Sarah’s friends is Katherine ­Grfiths, , who had been due to speak to her about a long-planned girls’ day out.“This is so out of character for her,” she said. “She always put the children first. She is a very special person and I am praying she will come back safely.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry fiji tour ceremony
story: Glowing Meghan spoke about how the journey of higher education is an incredible, impactful and pivotal one during a trip to the University of the South Pacic.She said: I am also fully aware of market.But it was cut short due to a security risk, with Kensington Palace blaming the huge crowds.The -year-old was being given a tour when security forces intervened.Harry, , had earlier laid a wreath and met Fijian war veterans without his pregnant we.Meghan who has already skipped events in Australia, arrived later in the day to give her first speech of the royal tour.The couple were met create incredible futures, not only for themselves but also for those around them.After the uni visit Harry made a trip to Colo-i-Suva Forest Park with Meghan heading to the British High Commissioners Residence and Suva Market.She was rushed through her visit to the indoor market in Fijis capital over apparent concerns about the locations security.Earlier in the day Harry left a touching personal title: cabinet meltdown if brexit goes wrong
story: Theresa May’s top table endured a heated exchange of views during a Brexit discussion yesterday as tensions boiled over.Revelation of the fresh dust up came as the PM prepares to confront all Tory backbenchers in a showdown meeting tonight.Ministers yesterday ided into two camps over how to unlock a deal with Brussels during an update from the PM on last week’s failed EU summit.Pro-EU Cabinet Office minister David Lidington called for more compromises to avoid the sort of economic meltdown that hit the UK when it span out of the ERM in September .The  year-old Tory veteran insisted that as the only member of the Cabinet who was an MP them, they “couldn’t have that level of chaos again”.He was backed by Justice Secretary David Gauke and Chancellor Philip Hammond.But Brexit supporter and Attorney Geoffrey Cox was said to have used “colourful barrister language” to warn that the Irish backstop could leave the UK trapped forever under the EU’s thumb in “Dante’s first circle of hell”.Former May loyalist, Treasury Chief Secretary Liz Truss, also backed Mr Cox’s call for a watertight mechanism to escape any temporary customs union backstop.And there was also a row title: kate middleton princess diana tiara queen buckingham palace
story: Kate, , joined husband Prince William, , and other senior royals for a spectacular dinner hosted in honour of King Willem-Alexander and Queen Maxima of the Netherlands.In keeping with regal protocol, female members of both the Dutch and British royal families wore ball gowns and tiaras.The duchess, who was appearing at her third state banquet, wore a dusty kingfisher blue Alexander McQueen gown - and of course that diamond and pearl Cambridge Lovers Knot tiara favoured by Princess Diana.Kate has also worn it to the Chinese state banquet in  and the Spanish state banquet last year. But it seemed she was out-blinged by Queen Maxima who was wearing an incredible diamond Stuart tiara.In tribute to the close links between the British and Dutch royal families, she perhaps chose to wear this fabulously jewelled ornamental band in tribute to the historical bonds between the neighbouring countries. The large stone was originally bought in late th century by the British monarch William III, also Netherlandss Prince of Orange, for his we Queen Mary II.Pinned to her left shoulder was the Elizabeth II Family Order is a jewel encased image of the Queen on a chartreuse yellow ribbon.Notably Her Majesty, , spoke publicly about Brexit for the first time.She said: “As we look toward a new partnership with Europe” the values shared by the UK and the Netherlands are our greatest assets”.She added that as innovators, traders and internationalists we look with confidence to the future.The Queen, who remains impartial in political matters of her realm, opted to emphasise the qualities needed by the UK and its closet European neighbours going forward as her government and parliament continued to be deeply ided by the issue of Brexit.Earlier, in a speech to both Houses of Parliament, King Willem-Alexander urged the UK Government to lt the shadow of uncertainty hanging over Dutch nationals living in Britain and Northern Ireland after Brexit.In his address at the Buckingham Palace dinner, with the UKs Prime Minister Theresa May seated nearby, King Willem-Alexander said: At present, a lot of attention is focused on the technical side of Brexit. Thats understandable and necessary.But in the midst of all that complexity we should not lose sight of the greater narrative that continues to bind us.The greater narrative of freedom, openness and cooperation. Of growth and a prosperity whose fruits are enjoyed by all.The Queen told the Netherlands head of state: I recall the state visit of your grandmother Queen Juliana and Prince Bernhard in , when I spoke of how our nations close understanding and relationship would become increasingly important as a new configuration of Europe was emerging.As we look toward a new partnership with Europe, it is our shared values and commitment to each other, that are out greatest asset, and demonstrate that even through change, our enduring alliance remains strong, and as innovators, traders and internationalists we look with confidence to the future.In her speech, the Queen also praised the close links between the UK and Holland which greatly contributes to the economic and cultural le of Britain.She added: The Netherlands are one of the United Kingdoms largest European investors. We have a thriving Dutch community, and artistic and sporting exchanges are at an all-time high.King Willem-Alexander reiterated comments made before about regretting the UKs decision to leave the EU, but he respected the decision of the British people.He went on to personally praise the Queen, highlighting her now famous appearance in the London  Olympics opening ceremony, describing her as the most fearless Bond Girl ever for her cameo role alongside  played by Daniel Craig.King Willem-Alexander also told the Queen and her banquet: In recent decades, you have seen your country, Europe and the world change enormously.The world looks to you as a trusted beacon in the midst of upheaval.Your ability to keep in touch with the times is striking.Meanwhile down under, Meghan Markle revealed her maternity wardrobe would be just as stunning as her pre-pregnancy style as she attended a banquet in Fiji. Along with Prince Harry, the mum-to-be attended a reception and dinner hosted by the island countrys president and opted for a breathtaking full- gown.The Duke and Duchess of Sussex arrived in Fiji earlier today as part of their -day royal tour.And -year-old Meghan couldnt stop cradling her growing baby bump as the pair attended a Fiji state banquet at the Grand Pacic Hotel.The Duchess looked beautul for the event and chose to wear a £, cape dress by London-based designer, Safiyaa.The blue gown is said to be in tribute to Fiji, whose flag is the same shade of blue.

title: napoleon tribute act emmanuel macron sun says
story: On one side, Irish PM Leo Varadkar is more a comedian than he is a statesman, though it’s not a high bar to clear.On the other, Emmanuel Macron, a Napoleon tribute act whose stature is matched only by his collapsing poll ratings ­— and who is using tough talk on Brexit to distract from trouble at home.But Mini Manu’s threats ring hollow.Does he honestly think French businesses will thank himhe brings a huge chunk of the £billion-plus trade between our two countries to a halt Does he honestly think French consumers are so annoyed about our decision to leave that they’ll want lorries blocking their motorways and supermarket shelves empty But Macron’s desire to wreak havoc on the UK economy as a Brexit punishment betrays the Continent’s fear that an unleashed Britain would leave the EU in the dust.We have no desire for our Government to enter a trade war.If Britain goes without a deal — and there’s every chance — then we will show Europe what they’re missing with tax cuts and a red tape bonfire that will supercharge the economy.A sensible French leader would welcome a deal that works for both sides.Time for l’enfant terrible to grow up.GOOD luck to Sir James Dyson in Asia.His new Singapore plant will give his thriving British firm a foothold in the world’s fastest-growing car market.And it seems to have escaped the Remainers crowing that Brexit-backer Sir James has chosen to build abroad that — by their logic — we’d have to boot Nissan out of Sunderland.Brexit is about building a free trading Britain. title: hair stylist flips mini cooper roundabout waving
story: Kimberley Howard, , was beeping her horn at a roundabout when she ploughed into a third vehicle being used for a driving lesson in February this year.Her Mini overturned in the crash and ended up on its side leaving Howard with serious injuries.She had to be cut free from the wreckage and suffered lost teeth, bleeding legs and a cut hand and was treated at Wythenshawe Hospital in Manchester.The driver of the L-plated Hyundai car escaped uninjured in the crash on a suburban street in Sale.Police investigated whether Howard from Timperley was on her mobile phone at the time of the impact on February  this year but found no evidence a call was being made.Tests revealed she had cut her hand on the phone when the screen smashed at the point of impact.At Manchester Magistrates Court, Howard who runs a mobile hairdressing service, admitted careless driving but escaped with six penalty points on her licence.She was also fined £ and ordered to pay £ in costs and surcharges.Howard said: I had left my friends house down the road that morning. I came round the roundabout and she was going a dferent way. I beeped and waved at her but I went round the roundabout and then the crash happened. I don’t really remember how it happened.”Prosecuting Tim McArdle said: “It was shortly after lunch time at around .pm. An eye witness was in her vehicle and saw a car beeping in front of her.“She believed it was to attract the attention of another driver. She was beeping at a friend as they travelled around the roundabout.“As she exited the roundabout the car swerved slightly left and hit the passenger side of another car which caused Miss Howard’s car to flip on to its side.“Miss Howard was trapped in the car, her hand was badly cut which could have been from her phone screen as that was smashed.“The police attended and described how after investigating a number of collisions suspected she was distracted by something in the car - it could have been her phone.“Although after checking there was no evidence of a call in progress at the time of the crash, it is unknownit could have been used for something .“She must have been travelling at some speed for the result to be what it was. There were no injuries to others. It was on a Tuesday afternoon in a residential area.”Sentencing chairman of the magistrates Caroline Green told Howard: “I understand you do mobile work so it is very, very important to have your driving licence.“But we need every road user to be conscious and you need to be very, very careful. If you get any more points you will be disqualied.“Something happened on that afternoon and it was a rather nasty accident, and it was fortunate that not more people were hurt.“Given the trauma you have been through medically to get over this incident, you need to be careful - not only for the next three years but for the rest of your driving career.”

title: brexit britain planning charter ships
story: NewsBrexit Britain planning to charter ships to bring in emergency food and medicine in case of no-dealThe cabinet has reportedly been briefed on the alarming new plans for no-deal doomsdayShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editorMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Britain is drawing up plans to charter ships to bring in emergency food and medicine in case a no-deal Brexit causes chaos in the English Channel.The cabinet has been briefed on the alarming new plans for no-deal doomsday, according to the Financial Times.It comes as Theresa May faces a make-or-break crunch showdown with Tory rebels tomorrow night as she bids to save her premiership.The Prime Minister will be hauled in for a confrontation with Conservative MPs to explain her latest Brexit plan which could keep Britain tied to Brussels until . She is due before the party’s  Backbench Committee where she is set to endure a tough grilling from angry Brexiteers. Today she ordered weekly updates for senior ministers on EU withdrawal preparations as the clock ticks down to departure on March . Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab will announce latest plans for quitting with or without deal every Tuesday at Cabinet, No  said.  Transport Secretary Chris Grayling has reportedly discussed the possibility of hiring entire vessels, or securing space in ships, to bring food, medicines and other supplies in through alternative ports. A Department for Transport spokesman said: We remain confident of reaching an agreement with the EU, but it is only sensible for government and industry to prepare for a range of scenarios. We are continuing to work closely with partners on contingency plans to ensure that trade can continue to move as freely as possible between the UK and Europe.Pro-EU Labour MP David Lammy said: Brexit has become like a declaration of war on ourselves.Emergency ships will be chartered for food and medicinewe leave the EU with no deal. But at least when were using ration books and running out of drugs, well have taken back control.  Prime Minister Theresa May has ordered weekly updates for her senior ministers on preparations for EU withdrawal either with or without a deal. The updates will be delivered at the regular Cabinet meeting by Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, who told ministers on Tuesday that good progress was being made on preparing for both possibilities. The PM, who faces mounting pressure for a breakthrough in talks with Brussels, was forced to listen to the King of the Netherlands urge her to lt the “shadow of uncertainty” hanging over Dutch nationals living in Britain after Brexit. It “truly saddens us” to see the UK quit the EU, admitted Willem-Alexander, who is on a State Visit to Britain. Speaking in the Royal Gallery in the Palace of Westminster, with Mrs May in the front row, he said , Dutch citizens in Britain and , Britons living in the Netherlands deserved “special attention” during negotiations. “Many of them have lived and worked here for many years,” the royal warned. “They feel at home in their local community and their contribution to society is valued, whether as employees, colleagues, neighbours or volunteers. “Every day they prove how good the match is between the British and the Dutch. “Yet all these iniduals now live under the shadow of uncertainty about their future status. “I understand how dficult this is for them and I trust this uncertainty will be resolved.” Earlier, Irish PM Leo Varadkar called for a solution to the backstop row aimed at preventing a hard border between Northern Ireland and the Republic in the event of a no-deal exit. “From our point of view, what Ireland is looking for is what we have always been looking for from day one and what has been committed to by us and the UK Government in principle and in writing on a number of occasions now,” said Mr Varadkar.

title: brutal saudi regime splashes 320000
story: NewsBrutal Saudi regime splashes £, on freebie trips for  MPsEXCLUSIVE: British politicians enjoy extravagant junkets to country which is responsible for the murder of Jamal KhashoggiShareCommentsByNick Sommerlad:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsMP Leo Docherty with crown prince of Saudi Arabia "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The brutal Saudi regime has lavished luxury freebie trips worth pound, on  MPs, the Mirror can reveal. On Tuesday reports claimed that body parts of journalist Jamal Khashoggi have been found in a Saudi diplomat’s garden in Turkey.We have uncovered the extravagant junkets enjoyed by British politicians at the hands of the country blamed for the murder which has shocked the world. Former ministers and a close aide to Prime Minister Theresa May are among MPs who have enjoyed luxury hotels, business class flights and opulent hospitality in the country accused of having one of the worst human rights records in the world.  The kingdom’s rulers were already facing fierce criticism for its war on Yemen, persecution of political opponents and a spate public executions even before the alleged execution of Mr Khashoggi in the country’s Turkish embassy earlier this month. On Monday MPs lined up in the House of Commons to condemn Saudi regime for their response to the allegations. But the Mirror has found that Saudi gts to Tories have risen ten-fold since the party came to power. In the six years before , the regime funded just seven trips for five MPs costing nearly pound,. Since   Tory MPs enjoyed trips worth pound, and six Labour MPs were entertained at a cost of pound,. Some MPs enjoyed multiple trips.  A Conservative party spokesman said: “All visits have been declared and registered in accordance with Parliamentary rules.” But Shadow Cabinet Office Minister Jon Trickett: “This list of shame shows just how cosy the Tories are with the Saudi regime and helps explain why they’re so reluctant to speak out about human rights abuses and the war in Yemen.” Over the same period, six Labour MPs have been entertained in Saudi Arabia on trips that cost pound,. Ryvka Barnard, senior militarism and security campaigner at the British anti-poverty charity War on Want said: “Some  million people in Yemen are facing starvation and thousands have been killed in relentless attacks by the Saudi-led coalition, fuelled by billions of pounds worth of British weapons exports. “The UK’s export control policy,properly applied, would result in a de facto arms embargo on Saudi Arabia because of war crimes committed by the regime.  But weapons continue to flow to Saudi Arabia because too many British politicians lack the political will to uphold the rules, stop the arms exports, and end this horrible violence. “This isn’t just negligence, it’s collusion lavish trips and rolling out the red carpet is just one aspect of the murky world of lobbyists who act on behalf of big business and corrupt regimes to wield an unhealthy influence on Parliamentarians. “MPs should be pressing the government to end its complicity in the war crimes committed by the Saudi regime by suspending all arms exports to Saudi Arabia.”  Seema Kennedy, parliamentary private secretary to Theresa May told Parliament that “the behaviour of Saudi has changed” three months before accepting a pound, “parliamentary fact finding” trip to the Middle East kingdom, funded by the Saudi Ministry of Foreign Affairs. As an example, she claimed that “it will no longer use cluster bombs”. After two free trips to Saudi Arabia costing pound,, MP Kwasi Kwarteng told Parliament in : “I do not dispute that the Saudis have, at times, been overbearing and acted ultra vires, as we used to say—beyond their authority—and that civilians have been killed. That is greatly to be regretted, and it is an appalling violation … but I do not believe that suspending the sale of arms to Saudi Arabia would help this country.” Leo Doherty MP, who has also enjoyed two trips costing the Saudis pound,, asked Theresa May in the Commons in March: “Does she agree that the kingdom is in fact a force for tremendous stability in a very turbulent region ”  Cabinet Office Minister David Lidington MP told Parliament in : “The Government’s judgment remains that a strong relationship with Saudi Arabia helps us to keep this country both prosperous and safe. It is in working with Saudi Arabia that we can encourage the changes we would like to see in that country.” In , he accepted a pound, trip to visit Saudi political leaders. Two months after a trip to Saudi in , David Amess MP said in Parliament: “I hope that the Foreign Secretary will continue to nurture good relations with Saudi Arabia.”  After a pound, trip to Saudi in , Simon Hoare MP told the House of Commons “Saudi Arabia is going through self-authored and hugely welcome modernisation and change.” Two months later, he accepted a second trip costing pound, to meet the King of Saudi Arabia, Salman bin Abdulaziz Al Saud. Six of the  Tory MPs who accepted Saudi hospitality since  are no longer sitting in the House of Commons. In April, five Labour MPs enjoyed a four day trip which cost pound, each. They went guests of the country’s Shura Council, which advises the king, to ‘discuss issues of mutual concern’. One, Mike Gapes, said he had a “long had an interest in the Middle East and the Arab world”.  Saudi Arabia is leading a coalition battling Houthi rebels in Yemen in a war which has left more than , civilians dead, according to Amnesty International, and up to , children at risk of dying from malnutrition, according to UNICEF, the United Nations Children’s Fund. Human Rights Watch said earlier this year that: “Saudi authorities continued their arbitrary arrests, trials, and convictions of peaceful dissidents. “Dozens of human rights defenders and activists continued to serve long prison sentences for criticizing authorities or advocating political and rights reforms.” Since , more than  prisoners have been beheaded by sword in the kingdom, sometimes in public and many for non-violent drugs offences. Activist Waleed Abu al-Khair is serving a -year sentence after Saudi Arabia’s terrorism court convicted him in  for peaceful criticism in interviews and on social media of human rights abuses. Blogger Ra Badawi was sentenced to  years in prison and , lashes for setting up a liberal website and allegedly insulting religious authorities. He was flogged  times in January .

title: halt universal credit roll out
story: NewsHalt Universal Credit roll-out to avoid plunging thousands of families into debt, writes Sir Vince CableEXCLUSIVE Lib Dem leader urges Theresa May to halt roll-out of flagship benefit scheme that has been heavily criticizedShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsLiberal Democrat Leader Vince Cable has urged Theresa May to halt the roll-out of Universal Credit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMinisters should halt the Universal Credit roll-out to avoid plunging tens of thousands hard-up families into poverty, Sir Vince Cable has demanded. Writing exclusively for the Mirror, the Lib Dem leader and former Coalition Business Secretary urges Theresa May to halt the flagship benefit overhaul until problems are fixed. Mr Cable blasts the Prime Minister’s “stubborn unwillingness to fix glaring flaws in its design”, adding: “The result is a slow-motion disaster.” But the frontbencher believes the theory behind rolling six welfare benefits into a single payment is still right. He says: “It doesn’t have to be like this. The Mirror are demanding a halt to the expansion of Universal Credit and for a review to take place. We say there are three options:Redesign UC to be fit for purpose Axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable Introduce a brand new systemSign our petition to stop the rollout of Universal Credit across Britain and to replace it with a fairer system by signing our petition. “The Conservatives’ failure to competently implement universal credit should not blind us to its inherent merits. “The Liberal Democrats supported UC in principle because we believed in its aim of simplying our convoluted welfare system and making work pay for those on benefits. “While the current Government’s handling of UC has left it on le support, Liberal Democrats argue that with a pause followed by some major reforms, the system could yet be salvaged.” Universal Credit was trumpeted by the Coalition when it was pushed through in the Welfare Reform Act  amid claims it would make work pay. But the shake-up, which begins to be widened to .million welfare claimants from July, has been hit by repeated setbacks and delays.  Ministers have now been forced to slow the pace of the roll-out. Then Chancellor George Osborne stripped poundbillion from its budget after the Tories won a majority in . Experts have since raised fears it will hammer the household finances of hard-up families. The Mirror launched our Stop the Universal Credit Cruelty campaign a fortnight ago setting out three options: redesign UC to be fit for purpose axe it in favour of the old systemUC is unfixable or introduce a brand new system. More than , people have already signed the petition. In a speech to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, Mr Cable will outline “three specic changes my party are arguing for in financial terms over and above the reforms in the way UC operates”. A single system replacing six benefits: Child and Working Tax Credits, Housing Benefits, Income Support, Jobseekers’ Allowance, and Employment and Support Allowance. It was launched in  as the pet project of Tory Iain Duncan Smith supposedly to make work pay. Who claims it  Low earners, those out of work and the sick or disabled. Already , people are on UC - % of benefit claimants. It is being rolled out to inidual Jobcentres including  in October . What are the problems  Debt-ridden claimants must wait six weeksfor their first payment, with % waiting longer than that and % waiting ten weeks in late . Research also suggests overall, UC leaves many working families worse off than the old system. That is because payments taper away at p for every pound claimants earn. The timetable has also been put back nine times since  after a string of glitches and will only be fully complete in late . They include reversing cuts to the work allowance worth around poundbillion a year, “which Joseph Rowntree Foundation analysis suggests would boost the budgets of . million parents and children - . million of them in working poverty, and take , people out of poverty”. He will also demand “improvements to universal credit for the , self-employed who will eventually claim the benefit, by extending the period before the ‘minimum income floor’ cap kicks in from  to  months and averaging income over several months so that people are not penalised for fluctuating incomes”. And crucially, “ending the benefits freeze a year early so that benefits are inflation proofed again, at an estimated annual cost of pound.billion in  ”.  Mr Cable will tell guests: “The overall cost is around poundbillion and we have suggested how this can be funded by ing the corporation tax rate to % and by taxing wealth more fairly. “There is a wide range of revenue possibilitiesthere were the political will to address the problem of funding UC properly.” The switch to UC was plunged into disarray this month after the Work and Pensions Secretary Esther McVey admitted some families would be worse off. Former PM Gordon Brown labelled it “cruel and shyvindictive”, while fellow former premier Sir John Major warned it could become Theresa May’s Poll Tax.

title: uk border may not ready
story: NewsUK border may not be ready for no-deal Brexit warns watchdogThe government need to replace the IT system and boost staffing levels...and the clock is tickingShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical reporter:,  OCT News "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMeasures to prepare the UK border for Brexit may not be ready for a no-deal scenario, a government watchdog has warned. The Government faces a race against time to replace critical IT systems, boost Border Force staffing levels and build new infrastructure to track goods, according to the National Audit Office. It said effective management of the border is fundamentally important and highlighted the potential for crime gangs to exploit any gaps. Sir Amyas Morse, the head of the NAO, said: Government has openly accepted the border will be sub-optimalthere is no deal with the EU on  March .  It is not clear what sub-optimal means in practice, or how long this will last. But what is clear is that businesses and iniduals who are reliant on the border running smoothly will pay the price. In a wide-ranging report, the watchdog found political uncertainty and delays in negotiations have hampered the effectiveness of departments border planning and delivery. It said many of the changes needed under a no deal scenario may not be ready for when the UK formally departs the EU on March . In particular, the NAO detailed how: out of  major projects to replace or change key border systems were, as of last month, assessed as being at risk of not being delivered on time and to acceptable quality New infrastructure to track and physically examine goods cannot be built before March Additional resources required to operate the border may not be readyBorder Force intends to recruit  additional operational staff, and increase numbers over the months following EU exit, the report noted. However, it said the agency acknowledges there is a signicant risk that it will not deploy all the staff it plans to recruit by March , . Signicant issues will need addressing to avoid a long period of sub-optimal border ing following a no-deal departure, according to the assessment. It said: Governments assumption that the risks will not change materially on day one is reasonable in the short-term but organised criminals and others are likely to be quick to exploit any perceived weaknesses or gaps in the enforcement regime. This, combined with the UKs potential loss of access to EU security, law enforcement and criminal justice tools, could create security weaknesses which the Government would need to address urgently.

title: universal credit isnt getting fixed
story: NewsopinionUniversal Credit isnt getting fixed for the Tories ideological reasons. It doesnt have to be like thisLib Dem leader Sir Vince Cable writes for the Mirror about the slow-motion disaster of Universal CreditShareCommentsBySir Vince Cable:,  OCT NewsopinionSir Vince Cable "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou would have to be hiding under a very large rock to not know about the serious problems affecting the roll-out of universal credit. The new benefit has been unravelled by deep cuts to its funding by the Conservatives combined with their stubborn unwillingness to fix glaring flaws in its design. The result is a slow-motion disaster which risks failing to achieve its goals while needlessly pushing tens of thousands of households into poverty. It doesn’t have to be like this. The Conservatives’ failure to competently implement Universal Credit should not blind us to its inherent merits. The Liberal Democrats supported UC in principle because we believed in its aim of simplying our convoluted welfare system and making work pay for those on benefits.  While the current Government’s handling of UC has left it on le support, Liberal Democrats argue that with a pause followed by some major reforms, the system could yet be salvaged. The first big problem with UC is a lack of money. Though initially designed to be more generous than the system it is replacing, in the  summer Budget the Conservatives cut around poundbillion per year from UC’s funding, making it in effect less generous. Many warned at the time of the impact the cuts would have on the poorest, which are only now beginning to be felt. According to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation – where I am giving a speech today- they are likely to push around , people into poverty by .  The second problem is a number of major design flaws which the Conservatives are refusing to fix for ideological reasons. The most well-known of these are the long waits - both for first payment and in-between payments - that are pushing many desperate households into indebtedness and food bank dependency. Another is UC’s policy of making claimants responsible for their housing benefit payments, which has led to a spike in rent arrears and a growing unwillingness of landlords to rent to people on UC. The Government argues that these design features will teach people to be responsible with their finances, but instead the Government should take responsibility and end the suffering it is inflicting on society’s most vulnerable.
