title: i diagnosed adhd after lifetime
story: News"I was diagnosed with ADHD at  after letime of struggling to control my focus" says ITVs Angus WalkerAngus Walker, ITV correspondent, has written about his ADHD diagnosis which explains his dficult behaviour earlier in his leShareCommentsByAngus Walker:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAngus Walker has opened up about his ADHD diagnosis"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A casual chat with a doctor led to finding out why my le has been at times chaotic, troubled and dficult. He was nodding away at my answers as he asked about my childhood. Was I often in trouble at school   Yes. Often in detention  Yes. Always being told off  Yes.I was a loud, chattering and annoying schoolboy. In fact, teachers allowed me to stand at my desk during classes because I couldn’t sit still or down for very long.Did I do well at school  No. I only passed four out of nine O’ levels, scraped some re-sits and left before my A’ levels were finished. Walking out after nine years of boarding school and ringing my Dad to say I had also got my girlfriend pregnant , you could hear the screaming from space.Had I been in trouble with the law  Yes. A conviction aged  for siphoning fuel from a car on someone’s driveway. I pleaded guilty and was fined pound from my dole money.  By the time I was  I had two children, had been homeless, mostly unemployed and for my middle-class parents I was a ‘lost soul’. For four years they barely knew where I was. I roamed around the country, in a converted lorry, doing odd-jobs as my family despaired and worried. As an adult, I’d find myself making impulsive decisions, often leading to a complicated personal le. Relationships failed, I have four children from two mothers. Despite the complications, we all get on and I’m very proud of my children even though I’ve often been an absent Dad. I look at friends and family and wonder how their lives can seem so stable and sorted. Why do I never seem able to stick at things and see them through  The doctor told me there may be a reason. A few days after that chat in the surgery I was sitting in a consultant psychiatrists’ office with a ping pong ball strapped to my head. I was told to stare at a screen and click when I saw certain shapes. I thought this was all ridiculous. The doctor had thought I had undiagnosed ADHD. I didn’t know what that meant, and was sceptical. I said to the psychiatrist that all of us forget things or have a limited attention span when faced with something we don’t really want to do. He, of course, defended the work he does telling me it’s not about an inability to focus but an inability to control what you focus on.  That sank in. I thought, yes, I’d often found it dficult to control focus, to think straight. Unless I am really, really interested and then I ‘hyper focus’. As a broadcast news journalist, he said, you’ve ended up doing a job tailor-made for people with ADHD. Always unpredictable, with constant stimulation and once the broadcast is over the team moves on to the next issue or breaking development. You’re never sitting still for long in a newsroom. I started the test, my legs soon jigging up and down, feet tapping on the floor. My head was twitching, and I was biting my lips with the effort to stay still and focus on this boring test for  minutes. The ping-pong ball on my head was measuring my head movements. After what felt like a couple of days, I was shown a messy scribble on the screen which had been traced by the headgear, and just how twitchy I’d been. Now I was told to take one tablet of Concerta, another brand name for the same drug as Ritalin. The tablet contains methylphenidate, a stimulant that can increase focus. “The drug takes half an hour to start working and so come back in an hour and a half and we’ll do the test again” I was told. A couple of hours later I started the test again. This time my legs and feet didn’t move at all. I stayed still. It was a strange feeling. This was the moment that, as the drugs worked, the penny dropped. I could be dferent, and I could focus, and I could stay still. The results showed a much neater pattern measured by the headgear. I was shown broken-down results which suggested in some areas of concentration the increase was % with the drug.  There was a sense of relief. For the first time in my le at the age of  I felt I had answers. Mainly to those around me, my nearest and dearest who’d always just said that’s “what I’m like”. Michelle Beckett, the founder of ADHD Action, a campaigning charity which tries to highlight the need for better diagnosis of ADHD says: “Almost every late diagnosed adult we speak to describes overwhelming relief at being given an ‘explanation’ for their challenges. This is coupled with an almost instant easing of the deep shame and guilt felt for ‘not living up to their potential’ or other ‘failures’ throughout le. Often these feelings of self-blame have lasted for decades.” That sense of grief then began, for the so-called ‘lost years’. Whatthis had been identied when I was at school  I could have developed strategies to compensate, known the dangers to my behaviour and take the medication that I do now. But it’s too late for all that. We can’t live in the past. I’m so grateful to the doctor for picking up on a few clues in a conversation. To the psychiatrist. To my partner Chrissie whose patience and understanding means so much. During Mental Health Awareness Week this year I tweeted that’d I’d been diagnosed. The stigma attached to ADHD, or any mental condition, meant I was wary of telling people at work but the response from colleagues at ITV News was overwhelming.  I tweeted as I was sitting on a train heading into work at Westminster and I was so moved by the supportive replies that I put my sunglasses on to hide my tears as I sat in a crowded carriage. Michelle Beckett replied to my tweet as did Tony Lloyd, CEO of the ADHD Foundation. I spoke to them both shortly afterwards and they were both so helpful with explaining how many people deal with diagnosis and coming to terms with dealing with the condition. There are so many misconceptions about ADHD. It’s often thought it only affects children. That it’s to do with bad parenting or other disorders. In fact, having ADHD often leads to depression or anxiety disorders. That’s also been the case for me and I’ve had excellent help from the NHS at times in my le. Men are three times as likely to be diagnosed as women and black boys presenting with symptoms of ADHD are often written off as ‘bad’, lazy or just rude. Adults with ADHD are nine times as likely to end up in prison and twice as likely to be fired from a job, according to #attentionuk, an ADHD campaigning group.  The problem for diagnosing ADHD is that firstly there is no biological test and then there are dferent types for example, some people are hyper, and others aren’t. People can spend hours focussing on the things they like, that gives them their dopamine starved brains a good-feeling and spend no time on the things that don’t interest them, like work or personal admin. Neglecting whole areas of your le is a common theme. Michelle says: “Around % of adults with ADHD suffer from mental health problems, and it carries a tenfold risk of suicide. It’s therefore totally unacceptable that so many GPs and mental health professionals refuse to even accept ADHD even exists in adults.” It’s even more shocking there is a postcode lottery of waiting times sometimes several years long, or even no service whatsoever. ADHD is stigmatised, misunderstood, yet highly treatable. If this was any other condition, there would be a public outcry. My le is now better and I now have the tools to try to limit the impact of ADHD, not just on me, but on those around me.Angus Walker is a Correspondent for ITV News. He’ll be sharing the stage with Rory Bremner at the ADHF Foundation conference ADHD in , Neuroersity and Mental Health, in Liverpool, November -.

title: legoland worker calls boy special
story: NewsLegoland worker calls boy with special needs liar and cheat during family day outJacob Johnson - who is undergoing tests for autism and ADHD and is on the special education needs register - was allegedly told he had fibbed at a concession standShareCommentsByAndy RobinsonHana Carter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsJacob was allegedly quizzed by the man on the concession stall at the park "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA boy with special needs was allegedly called a liar and a cheat by a staff member at Legoland Windsor Resort after he won a prize. Jacob, who is currently being tested for autism and ADHD and is on the special education needs register, was told he had fibbed when he announced he had thrown a ball in the target at a concession stand, his dad says.Furious Richard Johnson, , told KentLive: At about pm we said: Right last couple of rides, weve got to go home. We had been putting off going to the concessions stand as the odds are always against you.We go over to the first one and have the rules explained to us. The man gives my son three balls that you have to throw against the backboard and land in a designated area. He then goes to serve someone . My sons first shot lands in the area and then the man goes no you didnt do it right, it just went straight into the bucket. He gets all sarcastic going what you have got to do is this and calls Jacob a liar and a cheat. I go hang on a minute, hes eight-years-old, you dont call him that.  Jacobs mum, Caroline, , was horried to see her son upset after the man mocked him so she challenged the employee. Richard said: He said youre lying and that really got my wes back up and she said we are not liars. The attendant finally gave my son the prize and said wellyou can sleep at night knowing you have lied at which point my we replied we are not liars and he replied no not you, them and pointed to my son and myself. Deciding to set a good example to his children rather than getting angry, Richard went to customer services. He was told they would need to investigate the sitaution. Shockingly, he had to wait almost three weeks for an apology and he is still unsatisfied by what he calls a generic fob off email that he had to chase them for with persistent phone calls. He continued: I made a phone call and spent  minutes on hold to be told I needed to give it  working days and should hear back by October  but it takes a bit longer as the concession stands are third party employment. I said I dont care, hes wearing Legoland unorm on your property.  The trip had originally been a surprise for Jacob and his sister, Jessica, six, but the parents refuse to go back after their experience. He finally received a phonecall from their complaints department, and as an apology, they said that Jacob could choose any pack of Lego up to the value of pound - but Richard still says he wont take his family there again. He said: If I didnt go to all this trouble, I wouldnt have got anything. Legoland used to be a magical place but my son doesnt see it like that anymore. No amount of Lego bricks is going to change that. I dont want to go back. I want an apology for my son. I try to teach my son right from wrong but theyre not going to do anything about that guy. I feel genuinely sorry for the people who work in customer services there as theyre not training their people there or in the park properly. The lady admitted there was a failing in their training as this shouldnt be happening.  If they had turned around on the day and gave him a pound toy to say sorry we would have had none of this. Its been blown out of proportion because of their lack of customer service. A spokesman for Legoland Windsor resort said: We are very saddened to hear of Mr Johnson and his family’s experience at the resort, and apologise that on this occasion the high standard of customer service we expect from all of our staff was not met. His feedback has been escalated to the relevant management team who are taking the necessary action.

story: NewsMeghan Markle reveals she struggled to afford university during powerful debut Royal Tour speechMeghan Markle gave her first official speech as a member of the Royal Family during her visit to University of the South Pacics Suva campus on her Royal Tour with Prince HarryShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video watch-meghan-markle-gives-first-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:true,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email The Duchess of Sussex has spoken about the importance of access to education for all during her first official speech as a member of the royal family.At the University of the South Pacic today in Fiji she revealed her own personal experiences of struggling to afford college fees and but told of “feeling of pride and excitement that comes with attending university”. Addressing the audience with a traditional greeting of “Bula!” she told how it was “a great privilege” to be on the island. In her impassioned speech, Meghan said: “As a university graduate, I know the personal feeling of pride and excitement that comes with attending university.  “From the moment you receive your acceptance letter, to the exams you spend countless late nights studying for, the lelong friendships you make with your fellow alumni, and the moment you receive your diploma. “The journey of higher education is an incredible, impactful and pivotal one.” Meghan has previously been an advocate for women in her role for UN Women, the Duchess said the right to receive education is vital “for women and girls in developing countries”. She said: “I am also fully aware of the challenges of being able to afford this level of schooling for many people around the world – myself included. It was through scholarships, financial aid programmes and work-study where my earnings from a job on campus went directly towards my tuition - that I was able to attend university.  “And, without question, it was worth every effort. “Everyone should be afforded the opportunity to receive the education they want, but more importantly the education they have the right to receive. And for women and girls in developing countries, this is vital. “Providing them with access to education is the key to economic and social development. Because when girls are given the right tools to succeed, they can create incredible futures, not only for themselves but also for those around them.” Meghan also noted the Commonwealth, to which he husband Prince Harry was recently made a youth ambassador for the commonwealth. She said: “While progress has been made in many areas across the Commonwealth, there is always scope to offer more opportunities to the next generation of young adults, and specically to young women.  “The Association of Commonwealth Universities, which has Her Majesty The Queen is Patron of, supports universities to promote equality in their own institutions. I am pleased to announce today that two new grants will be awarded to Fiji National University and the University of the South Pacic, allowing each of them to run workshops which empower their female staff. “This means that female faculty members are able to encourage others to follow in their footsteps and enter higher-education, and that more women become part of the decision-making process in academic institutions. Grants like this ensure that women are provided with the training and skills to operate effectively in their roles, and those with leadership potential are given the opportunity to be heard and recognised at the most senior level. “It is wonderful to join you here today and we look forward to learning more about your academic endeavours, and the work you plan to do as future leaders and as change-makers! “My husband Harry and I, wish you all the very best of luck as you continue your studies and work. Your efforts now will help to make a positive future for each of you and your communities at large - congratulations to you all!”

title: mystery businessman wins injunction prevent
story: NewsMystery businessman wins injunction to prevent reporting of #MeToo allegations - but MP has other ideasLabour MP Jess Phillips urged victims to contact her, adding she was "done with rich men using our laws to hide you away" after the Dailywas gaggedShareByNatalie EvansUS Editor Brian Farmer:,  OCT NewsThe unidentied businessman won a high court injunction banning the publication of #MeToo accusations against him"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mystery businessman has won a high court injunction preventing a national newspaper from reporting #MeToo allegations against him. The Dailylost the latest round of a free speech fight with the company boss accused of discreditable conduct. Three Court of Appeal judges barred the newspaper from publishing confidential information after analysing rival arguments at a hearing in London. But one MP has vowed to help fight the gagging order. Jess Phillips, Labour MP for Birmingham Yardley, urged victims to contact her, adding that she was done with these rich men using our laws to hide you away. Under Parliamentary privilege, Phillips would have legal immunity against civil or criminal liability for actions done or statements made in the course of their legislative duties - for example, naming the businessman in the House of Commons.  The unnamed businessman, a senior executive in a company group, plus managers at two companies in the group, took legal action in a bid to stop thepublishing a story. A High Court judge had, in August, refused to gag the newspaper. But the executive and managers at the two companies mounted a challenge and three appeal judges have overturned Mr Justice Haddon-Caves decision. Sir Terence Etherton, Lord Justice Underhill and Lord Justice Henderson have outlined their decision in a ruling. They said five employees of companies in the group had made allegations of discreditable conduct by the executive. In all five cases complaints had been compromised by settlement agreements under which substantial payments were made to the employees who had complained. Both sides had undertaken to keep confidential the subject matter of complaints. The three judges had overseen a Court of Appeal hearing in September and published a ruling on Tuesday. title: terrified family plummet 26000ft plane
story: NewsTerried family plummet ,ft in plane after cockpit window shattersThe Mitchell family were on their way home from a holiday in Florida when a window in the cabin shatteredShareCommentsByIan BuntingHana Carter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT News "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA family feared for their lives as a cockpit window shattered and their plane plummeted , feet. Iain Mitchell, his we Audrey and their son Innes were flying back from Florida when to their horror a window shattered and the plane began to rapidly decend. The Boeing , due to land in Iceland, started to drop over Canada, causing panic to spread throughout the cabin.Iain, , told the Daily Record : “We were flying home from Orlando to Iceland, then onwards to Glasgow.“I had just taken some medication and said to my we that I was probably going to fall asleep as I had to drive to Castle Douglas to pick up our dogs when we got home. “The next thing I know I was wakened from my sleep by Audrey punching me in the side saying, ‘something is happening’. “The air hostess then said, ‘tables up, tables up we are going to have to land’.  Terried, Innes, , was so scared that he asked his dadthey were going to survive the journey. He said: No-one knew what was happening but Audrey said the plane was going down and the turbulence was pretty bad you could see the nose of the plane was pointing downwards. We dropped , feet in less than  minutes and my son turned to me and asked, ‘are we going to die ’ “I said no and tried to reassure him, then the captain announced that ‘all systems were go’ but we had to land. “It wasn’t your normal smooth landing it was all a bit rocky and you could see lots of emergency vehicles on the runway. “We were all very shaken up and were sat on the tarmac waiting to get off the plane when the captain announced a window had shattered in the cockpit.” The Icelandair plane carrying the stunned Mitchell family and the other  passengers and seven crew members emergency landed in Bagotville, km north of Quebec City. Iain said: “We didn’t know where we were all we knew was that it was Canada.  “One of the passengers said she worked for Icelandair and became the spokeswoman for the airline. She told passengers they were being taken to local hotels and we stood in line waiting for buses. “We were quite lucky as a lot of other families were split into dferent rooms but we got one together. The hotel actually ran out of food as it obviously wasn’t expecting as many guests to arrive all at once. “We spent the night in the hotel and the next day we were sat on couches in the lobby when we were interviewed by journalists. “We then got the call at about .pm to say that another plane had arrived from Iceland to take us there and we got back on the bus to the airport. When we got there you could see the plane we landed in was still on the runway and it made us realise how lucky we all were.”  Iain, Audrey and Innes arrived back at Glasgow Airport on Sunday morning –  hours later than scheduled – and though now safely back home on Carnbroe soil, are still “shattered and exhausted” by their terrying experience. “We’re all pretty exhausted and just so glad to be home safe and sound. “We haven’t heard from Icelandair since the incident happened, but another passenger on the plane, who said he was with the airline, told us the cockpit window hadn’t been hit by anything and it had been a technical issue. “He added that it had been a cm crack that started to spider.” The Mitchell family holiday in Orlando every year and have mixed views on whether their frightening flight would put them off future air travel. Iain said: “Audrey is saying she doesn’t think she could fly again, but I’ve already been on the phone booking the villa for Orlando next year! “I think we will all be back on a plane again it’s just the horrendous shock we’ve all been through is still very raw.” An Icelandair statement read: “The aircraft was on route over Canada when pilots noticed a crack in one of the cockpit windows. Following standard procedures, they erted to a nearby airport in Bagotville .”

story: NewsWoman removes ALL mirrors from home after being glassed in face on night outWARNING: DISTRESSING IMAGES - Abbie Watson, , who works as a carer, was on a night out when Demi Marshall smashed a wine glass in her faceShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsAbbie Watson, , removed all the mirrors from her house after a woman smashed a wine glass into her face on a night out "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA young woman has removed all the mirrors from her home after being glassed in the face on a night out. Abbie Watson, , was left unable to look at her reflection for months after a woman smashed a wine glass in her face. The carer and her boyfriend James Glasby, , were on a night out when trainee beautician Demi Marshall glassed her, leaving her in a pool of blood and causing her to pass out.Mr Glasby lost his wallet while they were out in the pub in February and they asked Marshallshe had seen it, reports WalesOnline .But Marshall, , saw red and smashed a glass with some force into Abbies face, before thrusting it into her cheek and dragging it down.  Abbie said: Her reaction was explosive. She was screaming at me and just lost it. I turned around to confront her but in that same moment she lunged at me and jabbed at my face with a smashed wine glass. She had whacked her glass on the bar to break it and in a split second had thrust it into my cheek and dragged it down. I was freezing, everyone in the pub was piling their coats on me as I waited for an ambulance. My boyfriend was distraught, he was trying to tell me it would be okay but I could see how scared he was.  When my mum saw my face she just screamed. Ill never forget it. While in hospital, Abbie needed two blood transfusions and an operation to close the wound in her face. In total, she had  stitches and has been left with zig-zag scars across her face. Abbie was left with facial injuries, including a wound by her eye and a fractured cheek bone. Marshall was later jailed for six years in September for the incident, which lasted between  seconds and a minute.In a victim impact statement read out at Cardf Crown Court, Abbie said: This incident has ruined my le. Abbie said at the time of the sentencing that she had not been able to look at her reflection for months, and had to take down all the mirrors in the house because I found it too upsetting. She added she was so embarrassed about the scars on her face that she used the back door at her doctors surgery.  Marshall, of Clytha Square in Newport, denied wounding with intent to inflict grievous bodily harm, but was found guilty by a jury after trial. The court was told that Marshall has two children and had no previous convictions or cautions. She had been studying at college in Nantgarw for qualications as a beautician. Abbie said: Demi was given six years in prison but shell only serve three. Its not enough for the terrible trauma Ive suffered.  I didnt look in a mirror or go outside my front door for three months. Im  and Im on anti-depressants, Im too scared to go out alone, I dont want to go back to work yet. It feels like my le is over.  Sentencing Marshall in September, Recorder David Elias QC said: What you did caused terrible facial injuries. Being scarred at all is bad enough, but being scarred in that way to the face means there is a constant reminder of what happened. Causing these sorts of injuries, with these consequences, must be met with the proper sentence.” He found her intention was formed on the spur of the moment.

story: NewsLonely office worker buys adorable puppy from breeder only to discover it is a RATThe creatures owner thought something was wrong because it didnt run like a dogShareCommentsByHana Carter:,  OCT Updated:,  OCT NewsThe man became more concerned about his four-legged friend as it grew "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA man in china was shocked after the puppy he bought for cheap from a dog dealer was actually a bamboo rat. Speaking to Chinese media, he said as his little furry friend began to grow, he started to have his doubts over the authenticity of the animal. According to btime, he felt something was wrong as the pooch was behaving weird and didnt run like a dog. Perplexed by the four-legged creature, he took to social media to seek advice. He shared pictures of his new dog on Weibo in the hope that someone may be able to tell him what it was. Small, with large ears and short legs, the animal was very identied as a bamboo rat, a rodent commonly found in Southern China, Burma and Vietnam.  As their name would reveal, the rodents feed on bamboo, as well as the roots of plants. They live in forests and grassy area and can measure up to cm with a cm tail. They are in fact a source of food for the Chinese, which can be found cooked in markets across the country. They also carry disease-causing mould, Penicillium marneffei.  According to local media, the dealer sold him the black dog for cheap. Shocked by the blunder, the man apparently gave his fake pup away due to not knowing how to care properly for the rat. The Mirror has been unable to very the claims, but the animal bears many resemblances to a hairless guinea pig.

title: besty lounge at dundee pub pays tribute to inspirational tracey
story: A lounge in a Dundee pub has been named after an “inspirational” woman who lost her battle with cancer last month.Tracey Burke, from Ardler, died on September , having fought the disease for three years.Tracey, , was planning her wedding day with husband Greg, , when she was given the devastating news she had cervical cancer.After a long period of gruelling treatment, she died surrounded by her family in the Roxburghe House hospice, her battle with the illness having touched people across Tayside.In just six weeks, the public raised a staggering £, to send her to Germany for immunotherapy, a pioneering treatment to try to cure her.The hashtag #teambesty was used on social media by supporters raising cash to highlight Tracey’s cause.Now, the Stobswell Bar on Dura Street has opened The Besty Lounge in Tracey’s honour.Greg said: “The Stobswell is our local – we were always in there. They’ve put the big sign up, but there’s also a collage of photos of Tracey in the corner, which is lovely.“It’s not a temporary thing either – it’s going to permanently be the Besty Lounge.“It’s a great tribute to Tracey and it was quite emotional seeing all the pictures. It was amazing to see just how loved she was and what high regard she was held in.”Greg is in the process of setting up a charity using the “besty” name to help local people with health problems. He will be a trustee along with Tracey’s mum, Pat, and other family members and friends.With some funds still in the coffers from the fundraising, Greg and the other trustees are looking to donate money to Perth youngster Lily Douglas.The -year-old was due to start cancer treatment in Spain on Monday. She was diagnosed with an aggressive form of lung cancer last month.She received the devastating news after being given the all-clear from stage four Ewing’s sarcoma, a rare form of bone cancer, having endured  rounds of chemotherapy.Mum Jane has now taken Lily to Spain where she will receive an alternative treatment to chemotherapy.Greg added: “Sending her abroad for pioneering treatment, which is what we did for Tracey, made it feel close to home.“I know what they are going through.“To be able to help them would make me feel so much better.”

story: Planning permission has been granted to transform part of a Broughty Ferry pub.The Eagle Coaching Inn on King Street was given approval to extend the public house.A single-storey extension will be added to the rear of the two-storey building.The space will accommodate a disabled toilet.This will allow the pub to be compliant with the Disability Discrimination Act.An application was submitted in August to extend into the courtyard.None of the structural improvement will be seen from the street.Internally, it is proposed that the end of the bar area will be opened up to allow better access between the bar and the courtyard area.Existing features within the premises are set to be retained during the proposed changes.

title: dundee born fashion wizard launches new range inspired by justin timberlake paris hilton and lindsey lohan
story: A Dundee-born clothes designer has launched a new fashion range in his adoptive Australia.Alex Maciver, a former Morgan Academy pupil, has created Premium Trash alongside friends Luke Meakins and Kelly Price.The brand’s new limited edition collection is inspired by early s celebrity culture, with nods to the likes of Britney Spears, Justin Timberlake, Paris Hilton and Lindsey Lohan.The look is combined with Alex’s Scottish roots, with tartan trousers and kilts thrown into the mix.Alex, who now lives in Perth, Western Australia, was awarded the dux in art during his final year at Morgan in  and graduated with a Fine Art degree from Duncan of Jordanstone in , before moving to the southern hemisphere.He has found success in his adopted homeland, being a finalist in the Australian Hair Fashion Awards Fashion Stylist of the Year for both  and .Alex said that although he is based thousands of miles away from the City of Discovery, he is still “proud” of his Dundonian roots.The range is set to launch this year, with the trio finalising products for release.n Picture shows the Premium Trash team – Kelly Price, Luke Meakins and Alex Maciver wearing some of the garments.

title: dundee people exploring jamaica through the lens
story: Pictures commissioned by a historic Dundee card factory will form part of a new exhibition exploring links between Jamaica and Scotland.Moving Jamaica: Scottish-Caribbean Connections and Local-Global Journeys contrasts photographs of the country taken by Valentine  Sons in the th Century with those taken by contemporary photographers.The show features a large selection of images snapped in  by photographers working for Valentines, the iconic greetings card factory based on the Kingsway.Established in  by John Valentine, the company grew to become a world-leading photographic company, sending employees around the world to snap idyllic images of exotic holiday destinations to sell as postcards.The black and white pictures of Jamaican le at the turn of the century are in stark contrast to the vivid colour images taken by modern day photographers Varun Baker, from Jamaica, and Stephen McLaren, of Scotland, which form the other half of the exhibition.The display opened on Saturday, October  at the University of Dundee’s Lamb Gallery, as part of the its Festival of the Future. vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"   vw, px"  Dr Susan Mains, a lecturer in geography at the university and curator of the exhibition, said: “I first saw the Valentine  Sons photographs in  when I was working at the University of the West Indies in Jamaica.“When I ed to Dundee in  I realised how amazing the connection was.“Valentine  Sons was one of the world’s largest photographic companies and sent photographers around the world to create images for postcards.“It’s fascinating to contrast their views of Jamaica with those of today.“The company was so important in providing tourist destinations. We think of tourism as a recent thing but there’s a historical context to that.“I wanted to show that Jamaica is a very erse place and there are links across the Atlantic to Scotland.“Scotland has had an influence on Jamaica and, in turn, Jamaica has had an influence on Scotland.“Photographs provide a map to frame how we understand the world.“We want to create a conversation between people living in Scotland and Jamaica.“There is a complicated relationship because some plantation owners were Scottish and, for a long time, there wasn’t a lot of public discussion about that.“When I was at school I never learned about Scotland’s involvement in the slave trade – it’s sort of cultural amnesia.”Susan said that while the Valentine  Sons images had played an important role in promoting tourist destinations, they contrasted sharply with the pictures of Scottish photographer Stephen.She added: “His series, Jamaica – A Sweet Forgetting, unearths the often hidden, but interwoven, legacies of slavery in Jamaica and Scotland.”Meanwhile, Jamaican photographer Varun’s work provides a personal tour through the current urban island landscapes of the country.The exhibition will run until Saturday January .

title: dundee people woodland walks leave kids full of autumn wonder
story: The kids at Ninewells Nursery have been having lots of fun as autumn sees changes to green le around Dundee.The children have been out and about learning all about colours and nature and had a great time picking their own autumn leaves.Adelle Taylor, manager at Ninewells Nursery, said: “The kids have had a great time visiting the local woodland and collecting their own leaves.“All of the children were able to learn about dferent colours and also dferent objects that grow outside such as conkers and pine cones.“It was fantastic for them all to be out and about discovering what they can find in the woods.“The children have been learning lots about the weather and autumn recently and after exploring the outdoors they came back to nursery and examined the leaves with magnying glasses in our exploration tray.“They also matched what they had found to picture sheets showing leaves, conkers and berries.“Everyone had a great time.”

title: dundees andy boyle shocked by mccann departure but we must move on
story: Dundee defender Andy Boyle admits he was shocked by Neil McCann’s departure as Dundee boss but says they must move on under new man Jim McIntyre.Boyle was one of the last signings McCann made for the Dark Blues at the end of the summer transfer window and he has made a good impact, so far, scoring in the - win at Hamilton – Dundee’s only league win of the season.And the Irish centre-back insists he wants to maintain those good displays under Macca as they look to rise from the foot of the table, starting at Livingston today.“With the new manager coming in it’s been quite positive and bubbly,” the -year-old said.“We had a quick chat with what the manager expects of us and what way he wants us to play.“We’ve had some good training sessions, full of energy and enjoyable.“As professional footballers we have to be ready for all kinds of situations and, either way, we knew we were going to be in on Wednesday morning and had games to prepare for.“From Tuesday when Neil McCann left there was no real indication the turnaround was going to be so quick but it was training as normal.“With the international break over the past week it was a bit of a surprise on Tuesday when the news broke but it’s just one of those things.“Neil was great at the time when he was here, in the short time I got to work with him.“We need to move on now, though, because we’ve got big games coming up over the next few days.”Newly-promoted Livi are flying high under manager Gary Holt and sit in fth place in the Premiership table on  points,  ahead of the Dark Blues.Their former-player manager Kenny Miller is now on the books of Dundee and Boyle admits the players have been using the hitman’s experience ahead of a game he feels they need to get a result from.He added: “Lads will probably speak to Kenny and ask him about what they’ll face in their dferent positions.“Since I’ve been here Kenny’s been brilliant, he knows the game very well and has a huge pedigree in the game so he’s a big help.“Livingston have the articial pitch and that will be dficult compared to what we’re used to but we showed against Hamilton that we can play on that.“We know it’ll be a test for us because, obviously, they have gone so well at the start of the season.“It’s a game we believe we can get a positive result from.”And the Dee will be hoping they can pick up some points as it doesn’t get any easier with current league leaders Hearts coming to Dens Park on Tuesday night.Although they’ve not had much of a chance to train as a group under Jim and have been out of the swing of regular matches because of the international break, Boyle feels they’ll be ready for the challenge of playing two games in four days.Boyle said: “As players you want to play as many games as possible.“You’d rather play games than train and the Saturday-Tuesday is a chance to get maximum points on the board and that’s the way we’ve got to look at it now.“It’s important now to get results and try to climb the table.“We’ve picked up of late and we have the confidence going into today that we’re more than capable of getting a result.“We’ll, hopefully, take that into Tuesday but today’s game is first and foremost.“It’s a massive game for us.”

title: new home sought for very intelligent chicken trio
story: A new home is being sought for a trio of chickens.The Scottish SPCA is hoping to rehouse Flash, a cockerel, as well as two hens named Frost and Snow.Scotland’s animal welfare charity is currently caring for the three birds at its rescue and rehoming centre at Petterden by Dundee.Dale Christie, assistant manager at the centre, said all three birds were friendly and would ideally live together at a home with some outdoor space.He said: “All three birds are well-handled and very intelligent.“They’re quite inquisitive too – they’ll follow you around the yardyou’re out with them.“Flash is an independent lad who enjoys showing off for his girlfriends.“You’ll usually find Frost and Snow pottering around the yard together foraging for bugs.”Dale added: “We are looking for a home for this trio that has a bit of land for them to roam around and enjoy the sun.”Anyone who can offer Flash, Frost and Snow a new home should contact the Scottish SPCA’s centre in Dundee on   .The rehoming centre at Petterden is open six days a week, except Tuesdays, from am-pm.

title: sse plans to scrap dundee substation and build 12 flats
story: Energy giant SSE is hoping to scrap one of its Dundee substations and replace it with  new flats.The power firm has submitted an application to Dundee City Council to build the four-storey block in Stobswell.The Buchanan Street plot is currently home to the former substation building and several steel storage containers which have been left to rust for several years.The new building could accommodate up to  two-bed flats along with car parking spaces and an access road which loops around the completed complex.The flats would be socially let, according to documents included with the planning application.SSE’s proposal is for planning permission “in principle”, meaning bosses at the firm want to seethe idea itself will be approved before investing in more detailed plans.If approved, the firm will have to submit an additional application before being able to push on with any work at the Stobswell site.A report included with SSE’s application, prepared by estate agents Graham + Sibbald, promises improvements to a “derelict and unsightly” area should the plan be given the thumbs-up by council planning officers.It said: “The application site is in a location where residential use is already established and the proposed development is in-keeping with the character of the area.“The proposed development will result in a signicant improvement to the site, which currently contains a disused sub-station building and steel storage containers, and is unmaintained and overgrown.”Colin Clement of Stobswell Forum said it was “great news” for the area. He added: “That area needs regeneration – that street has been left like that for decades. We’d be very supportive of that.”SSE believes the flats would suit the area due to its strong transport links, with frequent buses into the city centre available from Dura Street.Dundee City Council is now considering the proposal with a decision expected to be made by the end of next month.If it is approved, SSE would likely submit more detailed proposals some time next year.

title: were ready dundee council has gritting and ploughing vehicles at the ready for this weeks cold snap
story: Taysiders could get their first taste of winter this weekend as colder conditions move in across the region.Temperatures are set to plummet as low as C in coastal areas with snow on the hills and a risk of ice on the roads, according to forecasters.And the mercury could dip below freezing in rural parts.The cold weather will arrive on Friday and last until at least Sunday.It follows a run of milder weather with daytime temperatures regularly reaching the low to mid teens in recent weeks.Bonnie Diamond, a press officer for the Met Office, said: “It will turn colder from Friday as a northerly airflow becomes established across Scotland, with daytime temperatures in Dundee through the weekend of -C.“It’ll be bright with sunny spells at times, but there will be some wintry showers of rain, sleet and hail too, with snow falling over higher ground across the Cairngorms and Highlands.“At night temperatures will fall to about -C, giving frost and a risk of ice. Inland areas will see temperatures fall a few degrees below freezing overnight, with a more widespread frost and risk of ice here.”Dundee City Council says gritting and ploughing vehicles are on standby and weather conditions will be constantly monitored throughout the weekend.A spokesman for the local authority said: “There are approximately km of adopted roads and km of adopted footways throughout Dundee and about £. million is spent each year dealing with winter conditions.“It is not possible to clear all the roads and footways instantaneously, particularly in snowy conditions when the gritters and ploughs have to treat the same sections more than once.“Road winter maintenance in Dundee applies to trunk roads and council roads and footways. Our adopted carriageways and footways are categorised into priority and secondary routes and are covered for winter maintenance from late October to late March.“In adverse conditions, priority carriageways and footways are treated seven days a week.“Transport Scotland recommends that motorists plan their journeys ahead of timethey are using the trunk road network in frosty conditions.”This month locals basked in temperatures of up to C as unseasonably warm conditions swept in from Africa. The average daytime temperature for October in the area is -C.Dundee enjoyed the sunniest summer of the st Century with an average of  hours of sunshine through June, July and August.

title: BrightHouse to close city centre store
story: A CHAIN store which provides household goods to customers on hire purchase agreements is closing its High Street store.BrightHouse, Britainrsquos biggest rent-to-own retailer, has broken the bad news to staff.In a press statement the company said it would try to find stricken employees other jobs within the company.The firm did not give a closure date nor did it clary the number of staff affected.A company spokeswoman said: "It is with regret that we announced the closing of our Inverness store to our employees."BrightHouse occasionally has to close a store which is no longer profitable. Where this happens, we will seek to redeploy our colleagues and communicate to our customers the alternatives available to them."A spokesman for the Inverness Business Improvement Districtsaid the move obviously reflected a change in the industry.The BrightHouse closure announcement comes a year after the firm was ordered to repay pound. million to nearly , customers by the Financial Conduct Authority.It found BrightHouse had not been a "responsible lender".And BrightHouse last year announced that it was set to close a number of its stores as it struggled to cope with increased regulatory scrutiny of its business practices.This prompted a response from the Centre for Responsible Credit, which said it would "shed no tears"BrightHouse collapsed.BrightHouse did not wish to comment. The storersquos imminent closure comes six weeks after the Inverness Queensgate branch of the Royal Bank of Scotland closed and the bankrsquos High Street branch relocated to the Eastgate Shopping centre, leaving another empty shop.Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Fans shocked by city folk gig walkout
story: Music lovers at an Inverness folk night were left stunned when two people walked out in the middle of a performance.Hamish MacDonald, the first person to be appointed as Scotlandrsquos national scriever, or writer in the Scots language, was performing a song he had penned about US President Donald Trump at Inverness Acoustic and Folk Clubrsquos second meeting.The less-than-complimentary lyrics prompted two American tourists to leave MacGregorrsquos bar in Academy Street, where the performance was taking place.The folk nightrsquos organiser, Jo de Sylva, said: "As is the way in folk music, Hamishrsquos performance did court controversy. He had written a song about Donald Trump, which was very, very funny."It was his third song out of six, and the main act hadnrsquot even come on at that point."Most of the crowd were really enjoying themselves and getting behind Hamish, but this couple just grabbed their jackets and stormed out."It turned out they were American and they had been offended by the song."Itrsquos a shame because folk music is historically about getting people to talk about these things."Miss de Sylva said other members of the audience were left perplexed by the incident, and insisted that type of song is not unusual in folk clubs."Itrsquos exactly the kind of thing you would expect to hear in a folk club. The music is traditionally left-leaning," she said."You need to understand that when you go to a folk club, not everyone there is going to agree with your views."People were a bit taken aback."I waited until the end of the song and tried to go after them but they had already gone."It was very unexpected."Despite the interruption, the rest of the event ran smoothly, and tickets are already selling fast for the clubrsquos next meeting."Apart from that, the night was amazing," Miss de Sylva added."It was exactly what you want a folk night to be like."It was only the second event we had held but it is going so well."There are only six tickets left for the next event, and they have only just gone on sale."Itrsquos gone way beyond what we expected it would be."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Highlands makes it into tourist guides top 10
story: INVERNESS and the Highlands are world beaters ndash and thatrsquos official.Lonely Planet has named the Highlands and Islands one of the  top regions of the world to visit in .The area joins such spectacular destinations as Manitoba in Canada, Northern Peru and Piedmont in Italy as one of Lonely Planetrsquos must-see destinations for next year.The hugely-influential Best in Travel list is drawn from nominations among Lonely Planetrsquos vast community of editors, researchers and locals. These are then ranked by a  of judges.The region earned its place thanks in part to the whisky boom which has seen a swathe of new distilleries open.Lonely Planet said they offer "a great introduction to one of the wildest, least inhabited and most scenic parts of Europe".It also hailed a number of "unmissable experiences" ndash including dolphin spotting, the climb up Suilven in Sutherland and the regionrsquos sought-after seafood.A -day itinerary it has drawn up for tourists includes visits to Culloden Battlefield, monster spotting on Loch Ness, and the CalMac ferry journey between Stornoway and Ullapool.Tom Hall, Lonely Planetrsquos editorial director, said: "The wild landscapes of Scotlandrsquos Highlands and islands offer the ultimate escape and visiting the regionrsquos remote areas is now easier than ever thanks to impressive developments in accommodation."This is a stunning area with so much to offer travellers, from its glorious natural landscape and rich history to enviable local food and drink."The Highlands and islands feature fth on the list of top regions, coming in ahead of Russiarsquos far east, Gujarat in India, Manitoba, Normandy in France and the Elqui Valley in Chile.Business chiefs were delighted to hear the news, and said it would be a big boost to efforts to make the area a year-round tourist destination, and not just one that draws crowds in the summer."To those of us who live in and visit the Highlands and Islands it will perhaps come as no surprise, but recognition such as this is very welcome indeed," said David Richardson, the Federation of Small Businessesrsquo development manager for the region."What matters now is that we work to promote all the best the region has to offer and to increase visits outwith the season, as well as all the places that they can visit."Highland Council leader Margaret Davidson also welcomed the "splendid accolade."She said: "The fact that this endorsement comes from such a globally-recognised and trusted travel publisher as Lonely Planet will undoubtedly boost the arearsquos profile on a global stage and encourage more visitors to come and experience a true Highland welcome."Piedmont in Italy, home to new Unesco heritage sites, took the top spot in the  must-see regions.Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Medical professional sees his efforts recognised
story: AN NHS Highland medical professional has received a prestigious award for all the years and hard work he has dedicated to his profession.James Beastall who is a consultant trauma and orthopaedic consultant with NHS Highland received an honorary citation by the College of Podiatry.This award was presented to Mr Beastall at a special awards ceremony.It recognises the efforts he has continuously made to podiatry over the years.Upon receiving this award Mr Beastall said: "The award was in recognition of services to the profession of podiatry with whom I have established a close working relationship since my arrival over five years ago."It is a good example of collaborative working and the close relationship that we have established is certainly of mutual benefit to both specialities and it is a great example of multi disciplinary care. "Lord Kennedy of Southwark who is a patron at the College of Podiatry was among those in attendance. Mr Beastall said: "It was a real honour to be presented with this award by Lord Kennedy of Southwark, patron of the College of Podiatry."I was very happy to accept it at the annual awards ceremony in September."Chief executive of the College of Podiatry, Steve Jamieson, said: "The college is delighted to be able to recognise Mr Beastall and highlight his contribution to podiatry and the importance of collaborative working and patient-focused care."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Military Wives to perform at Inverness Town House
story: Members of Inverness Military Wives Choir are gearing up for a number of events to mark the centenary of the end of WWI.The choir is set to perform once again at the Poppy Launch at Inverness Town House on October .The singers are also due to perform at a fundraising event for Erskine on November , before hosting their two Remembrance concerts on November  and .The choirrsquos chairwoman Tracey Walsh said: "This will be our fourth year performing at the Poppy Launch and it is really nice to be able to go back again."The Town House is a lovely venue and we are all really looking forward to performing there again."Given our military connections, this is always a very busy time of year for us."Itrsquos so important to us that we donrsquot forget the sacrices that were made for us to enjoy the freedom we do."In the wake of the success of last yearrsquos remembrance concert, which raised more than pound, the choir have added a second date for the first time.This year they are raising money for Mikeysline, as well as Poppyscotland and the Royal British Legion."Itrsquos lovely to be able to support these charities and put remembrance at the forefront," Mrs Walsh said."The concert is something we work towards all year so it is really exciting."Itrsquos the one event we put on ourselves."We are really keen to let people know about the charities we are supporting."Mikeysline are a wonderful local charity who do a huge amount of work for the military community."Their work is so important. This year there have been a number of losses to suicide in the military so it is important that we continue to support organisations like Mikeysline."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Nairn hotel marquee plan is not on
story: ALUXURY hotelrsquos plan toerect a large "party tent" at the eastern edge of its grounds in Nairn has drawn criticism from neighbours.The townrsquos West and Suburban Community Council has formally objected to a planning application lodged by the Muthu Newton Hotel.The four-star facility seeks permission to set up a sqm marquee behind its existingsuite for wedding ceremonies and other events.Manager Murray McPhee saidpermission is granted the tent would be set down on a parcel of land unseen from guest bedrooms, protecting views.He said the hotel "always listened to the views of our neighbours" but insisted the marquee would be used "in a sensible manner" with all steps taken to ensure it did not cause noise and disruption in the area.But community council chairman Dick Youngson said the marquee plan was "not on" because there would be "far too much noise".The planning application lodged by the -bed hotel will be decided by planners in due course.Outlining the need for the large canvas structure in a supporting letter to the council, the hotelrsquos building consultant HHL Scotland said: "The Newton Hotel currently hosts between  and  weddings per year. About half of these weddings request an outdoor ceremony."Due to poor weather the majority of these end up having to be relocated indoors."The statement goes on to say that the hotel chapel "only hosts  guests, which is often too small to host some ceremonies"."As such, they have considered ious options and concluded that the provision of a semi-permanent party tent is the most appropriate option to address this issue."However, community councillor Mr Youngson said the scheme had to be rejected.He said Manse Road residents feared it would cause them endless problems and that they would find themselves embroiled in a noise battle with the hotel."This is just not on," he said."Itrsquos so close to the houses. All the celebrations and s will be unbearable for the families living there. Young families will be trying to put their kids to bed. There will be far too much noise."Mr Youngson said the intended location was the problem."Therersquos plenty of opportunities to have it where, where itrsquos not going to impinge on the houses," he said."They already have the tent and itrsquos a very good idea but therersquos no reason for them to put it there."We will be happy to support it on another part of the extensive site. They could put it in front where they have the cattle. Or on the west side where the stables are."They canrsquot have it where itrsquos going to cause problems for their neighbours."The planning application has attracted another objection from a Mr and Mrs Mackintosh, who presumably live nearby.Their letter, which is published with the planning application on the councilrsquos online planning portal, says: "Our objection is based on the evidence of existing experience."As is customary during weddings and similar festive occasions being held within the hotelrsquos conference suite the emergency doors on the south elevation overlooking the lawn are regularly left open."The sound of music and merriment provide considerable noise pollution which affects the adjoining neighbours for hours at a time."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Plans are scrapped for city street festival
story: CITY centre retailers hoping for a bumper week during the ninth annual Inverness Street Festival were crushed to hear the curtain has come down on the celebrations because of a funding shortage.The three-day event showcasing fire-juggling, stilt-walking and other top acts is not going ahead this weekend due to "pressures" on the marketing budgets of two of its three funders.Managers at the Inverness Business Improvement Schemeand the Eastgate Centre said a "dficult decision" was taken not to fund it this time around.Bid manager Mike Smith said it was "unfortunate" but times were tough financially and similar street events were being cancelled for the same reason up and down the country.And Jackie Cuddy from the Eastgate Centre said there was "a substantial cost" to running the festival. "Itrsquos tough out there at the moment and therersquos a lot of demand on peoplersquos marketing budgets," she said. "It was not a decision that was taken lightly but all parties concerned felt it best to take a break from it this year."She was not willing to put a figure on the Eastgate Centrersquos annual funding.Mr Smith said the total running costs for rsquos event came to pound,.The cancellation news came as a surprise for some traders at the Victorian Market, where moves are under way to boost footfall.Cafeacute owner Toni Rutherford from The Little Tea Pot said previous events raised the profile of the area."Irsquom shocked to hear itrsquos not going ahead," she said."It was great to see all of the people coming through the market."The festival was expected to run from yesterday to tomorrow.Last yearrsquos event featured  acts including the popular Granny Turismo and Pete Anderson, who climbs and performs on a ft ladder.The acts were expected to perform in the Victorian Market, and in the High Street, Falcon Square and the Eastgate Centre.The festival has also been supported by the Inverness common good fund to boost trade during the quieter months.Last yearrsquos event was described as the biggest and best ever by organisers.Mr Smith said his teamrsquos market research during the festival suggested more than  per cent of those who were in the city centre had turned out for the festival.Victorian Market trader Stephen Hastie from Hastie  Dyce Butchers said he too was disappointed to hear it would not go ahead.He said: "Hopefully it can be resurrected next year and itrsquos not a thing of the past."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Single mum left out on street by landlord
story: A SINGLE mum has slammed a "heartless" landlord for changing the locks on her flat, leaving her and her toddler daughter homeless.Kirsty Maclennan ed from a day trip to her mother in Fort Augustus last Mondayto find a note on the door of her flat in Ness Side, Inverness saying Albyn Housing Society had forced entry while she was out in order to carry out a routine gas inspection.The locks had been changed and the note gave her a number to contact to get hold of the new keys.With -month-old daughter Amelia in her arms she said: "I panicked."Ameliarsquos nappies and milk were inside and I have a bowel problem and wear a stoma bag so I needed in for my medication. I was totally stuck."The -year-old said she phoned the housing society straight away, asking for the keys, but claims staff told her the company had been trying to reach her for three months to get entry for the heating check.She said they suggested she "book into a BB" because it was not possible for her to get the keys that night."I didnrsquot know what to do," she said. "They were heartless."Without enough money of her own Miss Maclennan said a social worker eventually took her to the Fairways Travelodge where a single room was booked for her and her daughter."I didnrsquot sleep a wink and I couldnrsquot get Amelia settled until midnight," she said."I was worrying wondering what I was going to do. The out-of-hours guy seemed to be saying I wasnrsquot going to get my keys back until I paid a pound charge to cover the cost of a locksmith."Miss Maclennan said the keys were eventually handed over when she visited the societyrsquos offices the next day, with no-one able to explain why they were withheld overnight.She has asked to see a record of all contact attempts made by the company and is lodging a formal complaint.She claims the only contact she had with the landlord was on September  asking her to be available on the th, a date she turned down due to a hospital appointment.Homeless charity Shelter Scotland said: "This will be an alarming story for many people who feel housing association homes should offer real security to tenants."Instant homelessness without an investigation as a punishment for failing to meet an appointment seems like a disproportionate penalty, evena tenant is at fault.This was echoed by Inverness Ness-side councillor Alasdair Christie.He said: "This is a dficult and horrendous situation that a vulnerable mother has found herself in where the child needed to get into the house for changing and feeding and the stress that must have caused to mother and child must have been awful."A complete investigation by Albyn and their sub-contractor is what has to happen to make sure this does not happen again."After the Inverness Courier got involved Calum Macaulay, chief executive of Albyn Housing Society, said: "As a registered social landlord it is our legal responsibility to service gas boilers annually to ensure the safety and wellbeing of our tenants."However, we are investigating the circumstances around this case as it is clear there have been shortcomings in the service delivered."We are deeply sorry to have caused distress and we are in touch with our tenant to investigate fully. The pound charge has also been cancelled."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Tributes paid to proper gent 92
story: A SON has paid tribute to his -year-old father who died following a two-car collision in Inverness.Bill MacKenzie , of Firthview Drive, Scorguie, died when his car was involved in a collision with a van in Carse Road on October .Son Donald MacKenziedescribed his father, a former church officer at St Columba High Church, as "an outgoing man who was well known in the city" having lived and worked in Inverness throughout his le."My dad always very dapper and always wore a jacket and tie," he said. "He was always a very healthy and independent person."When he was  he needed a walking stick because he had a bad back. He hated that thing and said it was for old people."I had to remind him that he needed it because he was an old man."He never thought of himself as being an old person."He added: "He didnrsquot like the way the grass was cut at the local cemetery and did it himself until he could no longer do it due to his age."Father to Williamand Chrisas well as Donald, Mr MacKenzie also had  grandchildren along with a total of fourteen great-grandchildren."He was always devoted to my mother Lillian who passed away in ," Mr MacKenzie added."He was a paratrooper in  being too young to join at the start of the war. After the war he sold grass seeds and fertiliser to farmers in Inverness and the Black Isle and he embraced modern technology and often talked to relatives on Facebook or on Facetime."Of the accident he said: "I donrsquot know for certain what my dad was doing out that day. I think he must have been out to go grocery shopping."Neighbour Jimmy Grant also described Mr MacKenzie senior as a "first class neighbour".He said: "He was a proper gent. He always had a smile and always said hello. He was well liked in the area."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: Work at Stratton is streets ahead
story: A MAJOR new city housing development has taken a signicant step forward with the completion of an upgraded through route.The pound million Stratton development is expected to provide  new homes for Inverness, including  "affordable" ones.The first householders are expected to move in early next year and developers claim the project will deliver pound. million to the Highland economy along with almost  jobs during the construction phase.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael was due to officially open the new Barn Church Road yesterday.The new road includes improved junctions, pavement and cycleways to accommodate the thousands of residents who will eventually live there.Brian Clarke, from Hazledene Inverness which is leading the construction work on the development, said: "Our investment in Barn Church Road, the key spine infrastructure at Stratton, has been one of the most important aspects underpinning the whole development."Work will now begin on the residential, commercial and community buildings."Our plan includes the creation of green spaces, a childrenrsquos play area, footpaths and cycle paths."The town centre will be an open space with mixed retail and office premises, a health centre, community building and church."The provost said: "The new community at Stratton helps to meet several of the targets that we have for the future of Inverness, offering affordable homes, new jobs and local leisure and health facilities."Highland Council is committed to the creation of new opportunities and sustainable communities which will help retain a young and dynamic workforce in the region."Wednesday  Oct  : AM

title: heres the next set of roads to shut for work to bring superfast broadband to aberdeen
story: A project to install superfast internet is set to close a number of Aberdeen roads for more than a month.Areas of Torry will be closed while Cityfibre carries out work.Parts of Kirkhill Road, Old Church Road and Gregness Gardens will be closed twice each between November  and December .The closures have been put in place in order to protect public safety during duct-laying works in the area.A no waiting rule will also be put on the roads,  metres either side of the closures, with illegally parked vehicles being removed.Cityfibre is looking to make Aberdeen one of the three cities in Scotland to become Gigabit Cities.The firm has partnered with phone provider Vodafone UK to deliver full fibre coverage across the UK by .The works are moving to Torry after having previously started in Kincorth.

title: ice cream giants cool 50k gift to music hall
story: A performing arts organisation has scooped a funding boost after an ice cream company donated £,.Mackie’s of Scotland has committed to serving a generous helping of cash to Aberdeen Performing Arts over the next three years as part of its multi-million-pound refurbishment.The firm has agreed to gt £, and will add a further £, per year for the next three years to the charitable organisation and the renovation of the Aberdeen Music Hall.The funding will go towards the venue’s creative learning hub, helping to broaden access to the arts, promote youth arts and develop aspiring and established musicians in Aberdeen.Jane Spiers, chief executive of Aberdeen Performing Arts, said: “The music hall transformation is ensuring that it will continue to be at the heart of the city’s cultural scene for many years to come.“Mackie’s generous donation is a further extension of our strong relationship.“We have a great working relationship that included supporting last year’s Granite Noir and True North festivals, and this additional investment in the music hall is a further endorsement of our work in the community and with children and young people.“Plans are already underway for the reopening of the music hall after an ambitious, multi-million-pound transformation including vastly improved street-to-seat access, a new creative learning studio, performance studio, cafe bar, reception, upgraded auditorium and backstage facilities and historic fabric repairs.”The -year-old venue is to reopen later this year after an intensive makeover, which will also include the addition of three lts, allowing access from basement to balcony for people with restricted mobility.Marketing director and one of the firm’s three sibling owners, Karin Hayhow, said: “We’re all looking forward to visiting the music hall when it reopens after such an ambitious renovation project.“The new performance and educational opportunities this will bring is exciting for Aberdeen.“Live music from across the world will add to the fantastic repertoire of performance art and events already provided by His Majesty’s Theatre and the Lemon Tree.“We’re pleased to continue as the ice cream suppliers, providing a taste of the north-east to the Aberdeen audiences.“We now welcome this chance to give something back to our local community.”
